Where the charges for food and drink are satisfied by credit or deferred payment, the payment of the tax to the licensee may be deferred in a like manner; however, the licensee shall be liable therefor at the time and to the extent that such credits are incurred. 
(Code 1986, § 3-150) 
Sec. 6-266. - Due date; returns; collection fee. 
(a)  Generally. All taxes collected by any licensee or agent shall be due and payable to the clerk and treasurer monthly on or before the 20th day of every month next succeeding each respective monthly period, as set forth in section 6-261. 
(b)  Time of filing of return; persons required to file. On or before the 20th day of the month following each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period shall be filed with the clerk and treasurer's office, in such form as the clerk and treasurer may prescribe, by every licensee or agent liable for the payment of tax. 
(c)  Contents. All returns shall show the gross receipts from the sale of distilled spirits by the drink, the amount of tax due for the related period and such other information as may be required by the clerk and treasurer. 
(d)  Delivery. The person required to file the return shall deliver the return, together with the remittance of the net amount of tax due to the clerk and treasurer's office, City Hall, Milledgeville, Georgia. 
(e)  Collection fee allowed licensees. Licensees collecting the tax shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and paying the amount due, if such amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from the state sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-50. 
(Code 1986, § 3-151) 
Sec. 6-267. - Deficiency determinations. 
(a)  Generally. If the clerk and treasurer is not satisfied with the return or returns of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any person, he may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within his possession or that may come into his possession. One or more than one deficiency determination may be made of the amount due for one or more than one monthly period. 
(b)  Interest. The amount of the determination, exclusive of penalties, shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the 20th day after the close of the monthly period for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned until the date of payment. 
(c)  Offsetting of overpayments. In making a determination the clerk and treasurer may offset overpayments, for a period or periods, against underpayments, for another period or periods, against penalties, and against the interest on underpayments. 
(d)  Negligence or disregard of rules. If any part of the deficiency for which a deficiency determination has been made is due to negligence or disregard of rules and regulations, a penalty of 15 percent of the amount of such deficiency shall be added thereto. 
(e)  Fraud or intent to evade. If any part of the deficiency for which a deficiency determination has been made is due to fraud or an intent to evade any provisions of this division or other authorized rules and regulations, a penalty of 25 percent of the deficiency shall be added thereto. 
(f)  Notice-Service. The clerk and treasurer shall give to the licensee written notice of his deficiency determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail; if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the licensee at his address as it appears in the records of the clerk and treasurer's office. In case of service by mail of any notice required by this division, the service is complete at the time of deposit in the United States post office. 
(g)  When mailed. Except in the case of a fraud, intent to evade this division or authorized rules or regulations, or failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 20th day of the calendar month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period shall last expire. 
(Code 1986, § 3-152) 
Sec. 6-268. - Determination if no return made. 
(a)  Estimate of gross receipts. If any licensee fails to make a return, the clerk and treasurer shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the licensee, or as the case may be, of the amount of the total sales in this city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods in respect to which the licensee failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is or which may come into the possession of the clerk and treasurer. Upon the basis of this estimate the clerk and treasurer shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid the city, adding to the sum thus determined a penalty equal to 15 percent thereof. One or more determinations may be made for one or for more than one period. 
(b)  Manner of computation offsets; interest. In making a determination the clerk and treasurer may offset overpayments for a period or penalties, and against the interest on the underpayments. The interest on underpayments shall be computed in the manner set forth in subsection (c). 
(c)  Interest on amount found due. The amount of the determination, exclusive of penalties, shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the 20th day of the month following the monthly period, for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned, until the date of payment. 
(d)  Fraud or intent to evade. If the failure of any person to file a return is due to fraud or an intent to evade this division or rules and regulations, a penalty of 25 percent of the amount required to be paid by the person, exclusive of penalties, shall be added thereto in addition to the 15 percent penalty provided in section 6-269. 
(e)  Giving of notice; manner of service. Promptly after making his determination, the clerk and treasurer shall give to the person written notice to be served personally or by mail in the manner prescribed for service of notice of a deficiency determination. 
(Code 1986, § 3-153) 
Sec. 6-269. - Failure to pay. 
    Any licensee who fails to pay the tax to the city, or fails to pay any amount of such tax required to be collected and paid to the city, within the time required, shall pay a penalty of 15 percent of the tax, or amount of the tax, in addition to the tax or amount of the tax, plus interest on the unpaid tax or any portion thereof as set forth in subsection 6-286(c). 
(Code 1986, § 3-154) 
Sec. 6-270. - Collection. 
(a)  Action for tax; time for. At any time within three years after any tax or any amount of tax becomes due and payable and at any time within three years after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax, the clerk and treasurer may bring an action in the courts of this state or any other state, or of the United States, in the name of the city to collect the amount delinquent, together with penalties and interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. 
(b)  Duty of successors or assignees of operator. If any licensee liable for any amount under this division sells or terminates his business, his successors or assignees shall withhold sufficient of the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the clerk and treasurer's office showing that the amount has been paid or a certificate stating that no amount is due. 
(c)  Failure to withhold. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold the purchase price as required, he becomes personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price, valued in money. Within 30 days after receiving a written request from the purchaser for a certificate, the clerk and treasurer's office shall either issue the certificate or mail notice to the purchaser at his address as it appears on the records of the clerk and treasurer's office, of the amount that must be paid as a condition of issuing the certificate. The time within which the obligation of a successor may be enforced shall start to run at the time the operator sells his business or at the time that the determination against the operator becomes final, whichever event shall last occur. 
(d)  Money paid erroneously. Whenever the amount of any tax, penalty or interest has been paid more than once, or has been erroneously collected or received by the city under this division, it may be offset as provided in subsection 6-267(c). If the operator or person determines that he has overpaid or paid more than once, which fact has not been determined by the clerk and treasurer, such person will have three years from date of payment to file claim in writing stating the specific ground upon which the claim is founded. The claim shall be audited. If the claim is approved, the excess amount paid the city may be credited on any amounts then due and payable from the person by whom it was paid or his successors or assignees. 
Chapter 10 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 10-1-10-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POOL AND BILLIARDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Licensing, § 60 et seq. 
State Law reference- Operators of billiard rooms, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-1 et seq. 

Sec. 10-31. - Use of partitions, screens or other obstructions. 
    No person who operates a poolroom or billiard room shall permit any screens, curtains, blinds, partitions or other obstructions to be used to prevent a clear view of the interior, which clear view must be maintained at all times. No partitions forming rooms, stalls or other enclosures shall be permitted. However, this section shall not be construed to prohibit the maintenance of washrooms and toilet rooms for proper purposes nor the maintenance of closets for storage purposes exclusively. 
(Code 1986, § 12-151) 
Sec. 10-32. - Hours of operation; alcoholic beverages; notice. 
(a)  Poolrooms and billiard rooms shall be closed each night at 2:00 a.m. and on Sunday at 1:30 a.m., and remain closed until 6:00 a.m. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or operator, and/or any employee or agent of such owner or operator, to knowingly allow or permit any person to consume or have in his possession any beer, wine or distilled spirits on the premises of the poolroom or billiard room on Sunday, unless such poolroom or billiard room is authorized to sell alcoholic beverages and derives at least 50 percent of its total annual gross revenues from the sale of products or services other than alcoholic beverages. Any person who violates the provisions of this subsection shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any individual patron of a poolroom or billiard room to consume or have in his possession any beer, wine or distilled spirits on the premises of such establishment on Sunday. Any person who violates this subsection shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(d)  Any owner or operator of a poolroom or billiard room who opens such establishment on Sunday in accordance with subsection (a) of this section shall be required to post at least one sign, being two feet by two feet in size, containing the following information in easy-to-read printing if such information applies to his poolroom or billiard room: 
NOTICE 
It is unlawful to drink or have in your possession any alcoholic beverages on the premises of this establishment on Sundays. Violators will be prosecuted. (City Code section 10-32). 
    Such sign shall be displayed in a conspicuous and clearly visible location within the poolroom or billiard room. 
(Code 1986, § 12-152; Ord. No. O-00-06, 5-23-2000) 
Sec. 10-33. - Minors. 
    No person operating a poolroom or billiard room shall permit minors to play in such room, frequent the room, loiter therein or enter the premises thereof. 
(Code 1986, § 12-153) 
Sec. 10-34. - Inspection by police. 
    All persons conducting or operating poolrooms or billiard rooms in the city shall permit the inspection during business hours of the premises used as a pool or billiard room and all premises connected therewith by the police of the city. 
(Code 1986, § 12-154) 
Sec. 10-35. - Exemption. 
    This article does not apply to poolrooms and billiard rooms that are exempted by law. 
Secs. 10-36-10-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DANCE HALLS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Public dance halls, O.C.G.A. § 43-21-50 et seq.; application within municipal limits, O.C.G.A. § 43-21-58. 

Sec. 10-71. - Definition. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    "Public dance hall" shall mean any enclosure wherein public dancing is permitted or taught regularly or at infrequent intervals, for money or hire, but shall exclude places exclusively devoted to the teaching of children 12 years of age and less, and places where public dancing is wholly incidental to another business or businesses operated under the same management or as part of and within the same structure and place of recreation located on the campuses of schools within the city. 
(Code 1986, § 12-251) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-72. - Violations. 
    All persons who shall operate or maintain within the city a public dance hall without having first obtained a license therefor, and all persons who shall continue to operate or maintain a public dance hall within the city after their license shall have been revoked, shall be, on the conviction thereof in the municipal court of the city, punished as provided by section 1-6 of this Code. 
(Code 1986, § 12-252) 
Sec. 10-73. - Purpose. 
    Public dance halls operated for money, profit or hire shall be deemed appropriate subjects for municipal licensing and regulation within the city, and such regulations are made in the interest of protecting the public at large in the enjoyment of health and good morals and to aid in the prevention of fire. 
(Code 1986, § 12-253) 
Sec. 10-74. - License generally. 
    Licenses may be issued to persons desiring to operate or maintain a public dance hall within the city, upon the following terms: 
(1)  All persons desiring to operate or maintain a public dance hall within the city shall file with the clerk and treasurer an application in writing for a license, and the application shall state the name of the applicant, the location of the hall or place and the approximate number of times per calendar week that dances are contemplated at such place. The amount of the tax imposed by the council shall accompany each application for such a license. 
(2)  All applicants shall agree in their applications for license that their place of business or hall shall be subject to inspection during operating hours by the county, state and city officers charged with the preservation of the peace, and by their deputies; and shall further agree to conduct the business for which the license is applied in conformity with such regulations as now exist and that may hereafter be prescribed governing such business, passed by the council. 
(3)  Licenses applied for or granted may be refused, suspended or revoked by the council at any time, upon the return to the licensee of such portion of the occupation tax as shall at the time be unearned when calculated on the basis of time, in accordance with due process, if the applicant has violated, or if the license holder violates, any of the ordinances, rules and regulations prescribed by the city for the conduct of the business or the law of Georgia concerning such business, or should the licensee fail to preserve order at the place of business. 
(Code 1986, § 12-254) 
Sec. 10-75. - Regulations. 
    The following rules and regulations shall govern the conduct of the business of operating and maintaining a public dance hall within the city: 
(1)  The location specified by the applicant for a license shall be equipped with adequate and readily accessible fire escapes, plainly marked, and shall afford sufficient ventilating facilities for a group of persons equivalent to the capacity of such place; the sufficiency of the items shall be certified to the council by the chief of the fire department after an inspection of the premises by him. 
(2)  No license shall be granted for the operation or maintenance of a public dance hall in any building or structure in which any malt beverages, wines or distilled spirits are sold or kept for sale. 
(3)  No public dance hall shall be located at any place within the city, the operation and maintenance of which will tend to disturb the peace and tranquility of the neighbors thereof. 
(Code 1986, § 12-255) 
State Law reference- Fire escapes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-50 et seq. 
Secs. 10-76-10-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - AMUSEMENT MACHINES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Replays on coin-operated devices, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-111. - Violations. 
    All persons who shall operate pinball or amusement machines described in this article, without first obtaining a license so to do, or shall violate any of the terms, rules, regulations and conditions prescribed in this article, or any of such rules, regulations and conditions as may be hereafter prescribed, or shall operate such machine after the license has been revoked, shall be deemed in violation of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 12-116) 
Sec. 10-112. - Machines to be in exposed areas. 
    No pinball or other amusement machine shall be kept or operated, under this article, in a basement or cellar of any building, in a room where the public is not freely admitted, in a screened or veiled area within a larger room or behind screens, blinds, curtains or other hiding places. 
(Code 1986, § 12-117) 
Sec. 10-113. - Hours of operation. 
    Pinball and other amusement machines shall not be operated on any day of the week earlier than 6:00 a.m. or later than 12:00 midnight local prevailing time, nor shall they be used as means or instrument for the hazarding of money or other thing of value, or for the violation of any ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1986, § 12-118) 
Sec. 10-114. - Right of entry for purposes of inspection. 
    All rooms, storerooms, buildings and places where pinball and other amusement machines are kept or operated, and the premises connected therewith under the control of the operator, shall be subject to inspection during business hours by the county, state or city officers charged with the preservation of the peace. Refusal to permit such inspection shall be deemed a violation of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 12-119) 
Sec. 10-115. - Adoption of amusement device code. 
    The 1997 edition of the Standard Amusement Device Code, as published by the Southern Building Code Congress, International, Inc., as filed in the office of the clerk and treasurer and identified by the signature of the mayor thereon, is hereby adopted as the official standard amusement device code of the city. 
(Code 1986, § 12-120) 
Secs. 10-116-10-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-141. - Generally. 
    The council may grant licenses to operate pinball and other amusement machines in the city, subject to such conditions and under such rules and regulations as are set out in this article, and subject to such other conditions, rules and regulations as may hereafter be made by the council relative to the operation of the machines. 
(Code 1986, § 12-131) 
Sec. 10-142. - Licensee to accept conditions of article. 
    The acceptance of a license issued under this article shall constitute an acceptance by the licensee of all terms and conditions of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 12-132) 
Sec. 10-143. - Application; approval. 
(a)  No license to operate a pinball or other amusement machines shall be granted except upon the written application of the person who proposes to conduct the business of operating the machine, and no license to conduct the business shall be granted or issued until the applicant has been approved by the council and has paid the special tax levied for the conduct of such business. The application, prior to being approved by the council, shall be approved by the building official and the chief of police. 
(b)  The applicant shall provide his name and address, the name and address of the owner of the machine, the name and address of the owner of the business, the name and address of the manager of the business, the name and address of the owner of the property (building, etc.), the name, location and type of business (primary) where the machine will be located for operation and the date of birth, citizenship, social security number, place of birth, height, weight, color of eyes and hair and list any criminal record of the applicant. He shall also permit photographs and fingerprints to be taken and filed by the police department. 
(c)  No license shall be approved by the chief of police until he has investigated the applicant as he deems necessary, touching upon his character and reputation, and has checked for any criminal record on the state, federal and local levels. The chief of police or marshal shall have the authority to temporarily suspend the license on any machine pending further action by the council. The applicant will file the completed application with the chief of police. The chief of police shall file the application, if approved, with the clerk and treasurer for further approval or other action. On approval the clerk and treasurer shall issue a license in the form of a decal or sticker. Upon receipt of the license, the applicant will place the decal issued on the machine, inside the glass before the machine is placed in operation. Every machine must be licensed to identify the serial number and make of the machine. 
(Code 1986, § 12-133) 
Sec. 10-144. - Levy of tax; refund; renewal. 
(a)  The following taxes are hereby assessed and levied upon all persons conducting the business of operating pinball and other amusement machines within the city, the sum of $100.00 for each place of business where only one such machine is operated, and the sum of $100.00 for each additional machine kept or operated at such place of business. The taxes hereby levied shall be for the current year for which the tax is paid and the license issued. 
(b)  No tax shall be prorated or refunded unless the license to operate the machines is revoked by the council, in the exercise of its discretion, in which event the taxes shall be prorated on a monthly basis. Should the license be revoked because of a violation by the holder thereof of the terms of this article, no part of the tax shall be refunded. 
(c)  A licensee shall make a new application for a license by December 1 of each year if the licensee desires to continue to operate each machine during the subsequent year. Each machine licensed by the city shall be operated within the city only at the location approved in the application. 
(Code 1986, § 12-134) 
Sec. 10-145. - Revocation generally. 
    A license to operate pinball and other amusement machines and a license to conduct the business of operating such machines may be refused, suspended or revoked by the council, in accordance with due process, if an applicant therefor has violated, or if the license holder violates, any of the ordinances, rules and regulations prescribed by the city for the conduct of such business, or the law of Georgia concerning such business, or should the licensee fail to preserve order at the place of business. 
(Code 1986, § 12-135) 
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Collection of debts due city, § 56; licensing, § 60 et seq.; animals and fowl, § 74 et seq. 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 42; health and sanitation, ch. 54. 
State Law reference- Animals, O.C.G.A. tit. 4; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; transportation of animals, meat or meat food products, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-110; game and fish, O.C.G.A. tit. 27; civil liability for damage by animal, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-6 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Keeping of livestock. 
    No person shall keep, stable or maintain within the city limits any cattle, horses, mules, goats, sheep, swine, turkeys or chickens or other livestock. 
(Code 1986, § 4-1) 
Sec. 14-2. - Animals running at large. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner or keeper of any domestic animal to knowingly permit such animal to run at large upon the streets, alleys, sidewalks and parks of the city or upon any property of another within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1986, § 4-2) 
Sec. 14-3. - City declared bird sanctuary. 
    The city is hereby declared a bird sanctuary. It shall be unlawful for any person to trap without a federal permit, hunt, shoot or attempt to shoot or disturb in any manner any bird or wildfowl or to rob bird nests or wildfowl nests within the city. However, if starlings or similar birds are found to be congregating in such numbers in a particular location that they constitute a nuisance or a menace to health or property, and if no satisfactory alternative is found to abate such nuisance or menace, then these birds may be destroyed under the supervision of the chief of police. 
(Code 1986, § 4-3) 
Secs. 14-4-14-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Dogs, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-1 et seq.; destroying or injuring police dog, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-107; state assistance for control or elimination of wild and abandoned dogs, O.C.G.A. § 27-1-7; hunting with dogs, O.C.G.A. § 27-3-16; killing of dogs running deer, O.C.G.A. § 27-3-49; guide dogs for the handicapped, O.C.G.A. § 30-4-1 et seq.; control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq. 

Sec. 14-41. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this article shall be enforced by the law enforcement officer, agent or employee of the city designated as the animal control officer. Upon information known to or a sworn complaint lodged with such officer, that any owner or possessor of a dog is in violation of this article, summons may be issued by such animal control officer requiring the owner or possessor of such dog to appear before the municipal court of the city on a day and time certain, to stand trial for violation of this article. If such violation of this article has not been witnessed by a law enforcement officer, agent or employee of the city, a subpoena shall be issued to the person making the complaint, to be and appear on the day and time set to testify on behalf of the city. 
(Code 1986, § 4-16) 
Sec. 14-42. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating this article may be punished by a fine not to exceed $25.00 for the first offense, $50.00 for the second offense and $100.00 for the third offense. After the third offense, any person violating this article may be punished as provided in section 1-8, and the municipal court judge may order the dog destroyed, provided the owner is served with notice and a hearing is held. 
(Code 1986, § 4-17) 
Sec. 14-43. - Collar; inoculation tag; identification. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner of a dog to allow such dog in any area in the city without a collar which shall have attached a valid vaccination tag as required by the laws of the state, and an identification showing the name and address of the owner of such dog. It shall be the duty of each dog owner to provide a collar with identification as provided in this section and an inoculation tag for each dog, except when such dog is under immediate control of the owner. 
(Code 1986, § 4-20) 
State Law reference- Municipal control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-3; inoculation of canines, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-5. 
Sec. 14-44. - Procedure when dog seized or impounded. 
(a)  Any dog seized or impounded under any provision of this article shall be detained at the city animal control center. The animal control officer shall notify the owner of such dog, if known or can be reasonably ascertained, that such dog has been impounded. The owner of any dog impounded, other than the dog being held after the third offense, may, within three days after notification, reclaim such dog upon the payment of $1.00 per day for each day of impoundment, and the cost of a rabies inoculation and tag, if such is needed. Also, the dog owner shall pay a $10.00 pickup fee before the dog is released. 
(b)  In the event such dog is not claimed in the time provided in this section, the city may offer for adoption by any person any dog unredeemed or unclaimed by the owner upon payment of the costs as provided in this section, including the cost of rabies inoculation, if applicable. 
(c)  If the dog is not claimed by the owner within the time prescribed in this chapter, then the city shall be authorized to dispose of such dog in as humane and painless a manner as possible. Such dogs, if not claimed or adopted within the time provided, may be donated to any public or private institution for disposition. 
(Code 1986, § 4-18) 
Sec. 14-45. - Running at large. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog, or for any person having a dog in his control and possession, to permit such dog to be out of control and unattended off the premises of the owner in the city, upon the property of another person without permission of the owner or person in possession thereof or upon the streets, alleys, sidewalks, public places or other property of the city. A dog shall be determined to be under control if he is controlled by a leash or is within a vehicle being driven or parked on the streets or is within the property limits of the owner. It shall be the responsibility of the owner to have dog on a leash or chain, or within a fence or other enclosure. 
(Code 1986, § 4-19) 
Sec. 14-46. - Impoundment of dogs found running at large. 
    Any and all dogs found running at large in violation of this article shall be immediately impounded by the city or its duly authorized officers or agents. If the owner or person in possession of a dog is not known and such dog is upon the streets, alleys, sidewalks, public places or premises of another, any law enforcement officer or agent or employee duly authorized by the city shall be authorized to take possession of such dog and impound it, as provided by law or ordinance for the detention, control and disposition of dogs impounded. 
(Code 1986, § 4-21) 
Charter reference- Municipal pound, § 76. 
State Law reference- Dogs, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-1 et seq. 
Sec. 14-47. - Vicious dogs. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, permit, accompany or be responsible for the presence of any vicious dog on the streets of the city or in any other public places therein, at any time, unless and in addition to the other requirements of this article such dog shall be securely muzzled to effectively prevent it from biting any person or other animal. 
(b)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Vicious dog means any dog: 
(1)  With a propensity, tendency or disposition to attack, to cause injury to or to otherwise endanger the safety of humans or domestic animals; or 
(2)  That attacks a human being or a domestic animal one or more times without provocation. 
(Code 1986, § 4-22) 
Sec. 14-48. - Barking, noisy dogs. 
    No person shall keep or harbor a dog which, by loud and frequent barking, howling, yelping, growling or any other noise, causes serious disturbance to any of the people of the city. Such dog shall be impounded upon written complaint of four or more citizens living within 500 feet of any property upon which such dog is confined, pending a determination by the municipal court judge of whether or not such dog is creating a serious disturbance. 
(Code 1986, § 4-23) 
Sec. 14-49. - Confinement of dogs suspected of being rabid, when person has been bitten. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, whenever the county health office, the county rabies control officer or an officer or agent of the city shall receive information that any person has been bitten by a dog reasonably suspected of being rabid, the county health office, the rabies control officer or officer or agent of the city shall have the dog confined for eight days or as required by the county board of health. It shall be the duty of the owner, custodian, or person having possession and knowledge of any dog which has bitten any person or animal or of any dog which exhibits any signs of rabies to notify the county board of health and to confine such dog in accordance with rules and regulations of the county board of health. All persons shall comply with the orders of officials of the county health department in the handling and treatment of such dogs. Any expense incurred in the handling of any dog under this section shall be borne by the owner of such dog. 
(Code 1986, § 4-24) 
State Law reference- Animals suspected of being rabid, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-4. 
Sec. 14-50. - Injured dogs. 
    The animal control officer shall have the authority to humanely dispose of dogs which are injured and lying in the streets or public ways of the city whenever it shall appear that such an animal is injured and is suffering great pain and does not bear a tag identifying the owner and no determination as to the owner of such dog can be made with a reasonable inquiry or investigation. 
(Code 1986, § 4-25) 
Sec. 14-51. - Records. 
    The animal control officer shall keep accurate written records showing the final disposition of all dogs impounded by him, which record shall be open and available for public inspection. 
(Code 1986, § 4-26) 
State Law reference- Inspection of public records, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70 et seq. 
Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes:

State Constitution reference- Technical codes, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III. 
State Law reference- Buildings and housing, O.C.G.A. tit. 8; adoption and administration of codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25; fire protection and safety, O.C.G.A. tit. 25; service of process relating to ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2; bonds for public contractors, O.C.G.A. § 36-82-100 et seq.; electrical contractors, plumbers, conditioned air contractors, etc., O.C.G.A. § 43-14-1 et seq.; bonds for nonresident contractors, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-32. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Violations. 
    In lieu of or in addition to other penalties for violations of this chapter, any license issued by the city may be suspended or revoked therefor. 
(Code 1986, § 5-1) 
Sec. 18-2. - Liability for damages. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed to relieve any person from liability or responsibility for damages or injury to life or property. 
(Code 1986, § 5-2) 
Sec. 18-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Inasmuch as Ord. No. O-02-02, adopted January 22, 2002, enacted provisions regarding administrative procedures for the enforcement of state minimum construction codes, the provisions of the former section 18-3, which pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1986, § 5-3, have been removed from this Code at the discretion of the editor. For current provisions, the user's attention is directed to article VIII of this chapter. 
Sec. 18-4. - Persons working on own premises. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as prohibiting an individual from constructing, installing or repairing his own residential structures or appliances, or installing, extending, replacing, altering or repairing structures or appliances on his own residential premises, or as requiring a license or a bond from an individual doing such work on his own residential premises; provided, however, all such work must be done in conformity with all other provisions of this chapter, including those relating to permits, inspection and fees. 
(Code 1986, § 5-4) 
Sec. 18-5. - CABO One- and Two-Family Dwelling Code/International Residential Code. 
    The latest edition of the CABO One- and Two-Family Dwelling Code/International Residential Code, including the appendix, as adopted and amended by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, is hereby adopted as the official one- and two-family dwelling code and residential code of the city. 
(Code 1986, § 5-5; Ord. No. O-02-03, 1-22-2002) 
Sec. 18-6. - Energy code. 
    The 1986 edition, with 1988 amendments, of the Georgia State Energy Code for Buildings, as filed in the office of the clerk and treasurer and identified by the signature of the mayor thereon, is hereby adopted as the official energy code of the city. 
(Code 1986, § 5-6; Ord. of 7-26-1988, § 1; Ord. of 3-12-1991, § 1; Ord. of 11-24-1992, § 1) 
Sec. 18-7. - Unsafe buildings. 
    The latest edition of the Standard Unsafe Building Abatement Code, as adopted and amended by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, is hereby adopted as the official standard code for the elimination or repair of unsafe buildings in the city. 
(Code 1986, § 5-7; Ord. No. O-02-03, 1-22-2002) 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 42. 
Sec. 18-8. - Existing buildings. 
    The latest edition of the Standard Existing Buildings Code, as adopted and amended by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, is hereby adopted as the official standard code for existing buildings in the city. 
(Code 1986, § 5-8; Ord. of 11-24-1992, § 1; Ord. No. O-02-03, 1-22-2002) 
Sec. 18-9. - Swimming pools. 
    The latest edition of the Standard Swimming Pool Code, as adopted and amended by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, is hereby adopted as the official standard swimming pool code of the city. 
(Code 1986, § 5-9; Ord. No. O-02-03, 1-22-2002) 
Sec. 18-10. - Excavation and grading. 
    The latest edition of the Standard Excavation and Grading Code, as adopted and amended by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, is hereby adopted as the official standard excavation and grading code of the city. 
(Code 1986, § 5-10; Ord. No. O-02-03, 1-22-2002) 
Sec. 18-11. - Accessibility codes for buildings and facilities. 
    The latest edition of Accessibility Codes for Buildings and Facilities, O.C.G.A. § 120-3-20, as adopted by the Office of Fire and Safety Commission, is hereby adopted. 
(Ord. No. O-02-03, 1-22-2002)

Sec. 18-12. - Amusement devices.

Footnotes:

    The latest edition of the Standard/International Building Code, including the Appendix, as adopted and amended by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, is hereby adopted as the official building code of the city.

Sec. 18-42. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Inasmuch as Ord. No. O-02-03 adopts the latest edition of the Standard/International Building Code, the provisions of the former section 18-42, which pertained to amendments to the 1997 edition of the Standard Building Code and derived from the Code of 1986, § 5-22, have been removed from this Code at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 18-43. - Fire districts. 
(a)  Generally. In order to provide against loss by fire in the city, there are hereby created two fire districts in which the buildings and construction therein shall comply with all of the appropriate provisions of the building code of the city. 
(b)  First fire district. The first fire district shall include all of the area within the corporate limits of the city as outlined in red on a designated map of such city, and shall have such metes and bounds, courses and distances as are shown on the map, which is made a part of this section. 
(c)  Second fire district. The second fire district shall include all of that area within the corporate limits of the city as outlined in blue on a designated map of such city, and shall have such metes and bounds, courses and distances as shown on the map which is made a part of this section. 
(Code 1986, § 5-23) 
Editor's note- The maps referred to in the above section are on file in the office of the city clerk and treasurer.

ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICITY[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Adoption of technical codes, § 13. 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 90. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-81. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Electrical contracting and electrical contractor means any person, firm or corporation engaging in the business of electrical installations, construction and repair. 
    Master electrician means any person who shall have a current business license from the city to engage in electrical contracting. A master electrician is defined, too, as a person who assumes the responsible charge either for himself, or for directing of other persons in the installation of wiring for light, heat and power, and who is skilled in the art of electrical superintending, and has sufficient practical knowledge of electricity to efficiently and properly assume the responsible charge and direction of other persons in the installation of wiring for light, heat and power. A master electrician may be further identified as a person who holds a current electrical contractor's certification from the state. 
    Superintendent means the superintendent of electrical affairs. 
(Code 1986, § 5-81) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-82. - Violations. 
    No person shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply with any order of the superintendent of electrical affairs given pursuant to and by authority of this article, nor shall willfully aid or assist in the violation of any of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 5-82) 
Sec. 18-83. - Electrical maintenance excluded. 
    This article shall not cover minor electrical repairs involving no new work, alteration or change whatever, that may be necessary or incidental to the maintenance only in good condition of an established plant, installation, system or wiring or common household appliances. But this qualification does not extend to installation of new circuits or the extension of any circuits already installed, or the installation of any apparatus, devices or materials whatever for which a permit is required under this article. 
(Code 1986, § 5-83) 
Sec. 18-84. - Electrical department established. 
    There is hereby established in the city a department to be called the electrical department, which shall be in the charge of a superintendent of electrical affairs. The building official shall also be the superintendent of electrical affairs. 
(Code 1986, § 5-84) 
Sec. 18-85. - Superintendent's general powers and duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the superintendent of electrical affairs to inspect or have inspected all electrical construction, installation and equipment of whatever character, whether inside or outside of buildings, and he shall have power to order removed, repaired or rebuilt any such construction, installation or equipment when in his judgment, life or property will be better protected thereby; and it shall be his duty to see that all laws of force now or that may hereafter be enacted, governing electrical energy or construction, are strictly complied with. 
(Code 1986, § 5-85) 
Sec. 18-86. - Records; reports. 
    The superintendent of electrical affairs shall keep a full and complete daily record of all work done, permits issued, examinations made and other official work performed, as required by this article, and shall make an annual report thereof to the council on or before January 1. 
(Code 1986, § 5-86) 
Sec. 18-87. - Electric lights. 
    The superintendent of electrical affairs shall have general supervision of electric lights and shall require all concerns furnishing lights to the city to comply with the terms of their contracts with the city. 
(Code 1986, § 5-87) 
Sec. 18-88. - Right of entry for purposes of inspection. 
    The superintendent of electrical affairs shall have the right at reasonable times, in the discharge of his duties, to enter any building under construction or completed or any manhole or subway, or to climb any pole, for the purpose of examining and testing the electric wires, construction or appliance therein, or thereon contained. For that purpose he shall be given prompt access to all buildings, public or private, and to all manholes, subways or poles, on application to the individual or company owning or in charge of same. 
(Code 1986, § 5-88) 
Secs. 18-89-18-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 

Sec. 18-111. - Required. 
    Every person desiring to engage in the business of electrical contracting (construction, repair or installation) shall before doing so obtain a business license from the clerk and treasurer. No business license shall be issued until after presentation to the clerk and treasurer of a certificate from the superintendent of electrical affairs showing that the applicant is qualified under this article to engage in such business, or in the case of a firm or corporation that the superintendent of such firm or corporation making application is so qualified and all work is to be done under his direct supervision and responsibility. The fee for such license shall be as set out and established by the council. 
(Code 1986, § 5-126) 
Sec. 18-112. - Contractor's bond. 
    Before any person shall engage in the business of electrical contracting (construction, repair and installation) in the city, he shall first deposit with the city a good and sufficient bond in the sum of $10,000.00, to be approved by the clerk and treasurer, indemnifying and saving harmless the city from all claims arising from accidents and damage of any character caused by the negligence of such person while engaged in the electrical contracting business within the city. In lieu of such bond, any person may satisfy the requirements of this section by depositing with the city a certificate from an insurance company acceptable by the clerk and treasurer showing issuance of personal injury and property damage liability insurance as follows: 
Personal injury, including death: Limit of $10,000.00 for each person and $20,000.00 for each accident. 
Property damages: Limit of $10,000.00 for each accident. 
(Code 1986, § 5-127) 
Sec. 18-113. - False certification; violation by master electrician; hearing. 
    Any master electrician who shall have been licensed as such under the provisions of this article who violates any of the provisions of this article, or who certifies under oath to the superintendent of electrical affairs that he has supervised the installation, construction or repair of any electrical work, when in fact he has not, shall be cited by the superintendent of electrical affairs to appear before the council to show cause why his license should not be revoked. After such citation has been personally served upon the master electrician, he shall have the right to appear before the council and offer such evidence in his behalf as he deems necessary. At the same time the superintendent of electrical affairs shall offer evidence showing the violation as charged. After hearing the evidence the council shall then, by a majority vote, find him guilty or not guilty as the evidence warrants. If found guilty, the council may revoke his license or impose a suspension of his license for a period of 90 days. If found not guilty, the charges shall be dropped. If the person so cited to appear shall fail to appear at the time and place specified in the citation, his license shall be automatically suspended until such time as he does appear before the council and answers the charges. 
(Code 1986, § 5-128) 
Secs. 18-114-18-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ELECTRICAL CODE 

Sec. 18-141. - Adopted. 
    The latest edition of the National Electrical Code, as adopted and amended by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, is hereby adopted as the official electrical code of the city. 
(Code 1986, § 5-141; Ord. No. O-02-03, 1-22-2002)

No. O-02-03 adopts the latest edition of the National Electric Code, the provisions of the former section 18-142, which pertained to a city supplement to the 1999 edition of the National Electric Code and derived from the Code of 1986, § 5-142, have been removed from this Code at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 18-143. - Materials, devices, appliances to conform to code. 
    No electrical materials, devices or appliances shall be sold, used or installed in the city, unless they are in conformity with the provisions of the National Electrical Code, as adopted and supplemented in this division. 
(Code 1986, § 5-143) 
Secs. 18-144-18-180. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VI. - HOUSING CODE[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) ---
