ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 54-1-54-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HEALTH HAZARDS 

Sec. 54-31. - Prohibited storage of property. 
    All nonfunctioning motor vehicles, appliances, machinery and equipment stored, kept or maintained out of doors within the city are declared to be a public health hazard, and the placing, keeping or maintaining of any nonfunctioning motor vehicle, appliance, machinery or equipment on any property out of doors within the corporate limits of the city shall be a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1986, § 10-16) 
State Law reference- Abandoned motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq. 
Sec. 54-32. - Exceptions. 
    This article shall not apply to any motor vehicle, kept, stored or maintained upon private property, which has a current up-to-date motor vehicle license tag thereon, nor shall it apply to any vehicles, appliances or equipment kept and maintained in connection with or as a part of any duly licensed appliance, machinery or automobile repair shop or junkyard. 
(Code 1986, § 10-17) 
Sec. 54-33. - Administration; notice of violation; appeal. 
(a)  This article shall be administered by the city marshal, and if and whenever it shall appear to the city marshal that it is being violated, he shall, in writing, notify the owner of the property or the tenant in possession of the land on which the violation exists to abate such violation by removing the material or materials to a conforming location or into some enclosed garage or other storage house, within ten days from the date of such notice. 
(b)  Any person disagreeing with such notice shall have ten days from the date of the notice in which to appeal the decision of the city marshal to the council, requesting that the council make a determination as to whether or not a violation actually exists, which appeal shall be heard after due notice and as soon as practical, and the decision of the council shall be final. 
(c)  Any person who fails to comply with the notice given by the city marshal in compliance with this section within the ten days after the notice is given or within ten days after the final decision is made by the council (in cases where appeals are filed), shall be in violation of this section. 
(Code 1986, § 10-18) 
Sec. 54-34. - Removal of nonfunctioning vehicles, appliances, machinery or equipment. 
(a)  After the time provided in section 54-33 for the removal of nonfunctioning motor vehicles, appliances, machinery or equipment has expired, the city marshal is directed to remove such property from the premises and dispose of the same and charge the expense thereof to the owner. 
(b)  The city marshal is also directed to remove any abandoned or nonfunctioning motor vehicles, appliances, machinery or equipment from any public street in the city, the expense of which shall likewise be charged to the owner. 
(Code 1986, § 10-19) 
Secs. 54-35-54-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FOOD[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 54-71-54-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 54-91. - State rules-Adopted. 
    The latest edition of the rules and regulations of the state department of human resources pertaining to food service establishments shall apply to all food service establishments operated within the city. 
(Code 1986, § 10-31) 
Sec. 54-92. - Same-Violations. 
    Should it be determined that any food service establishment is in violation of the rules and regulations of the state department of human resources pertaining to food service establishments, which are adopted in this article as the rules and regulations of the council, ten-days' written notice specifying the violations complained of shall be given by the county board of health or its agents, or by the city marshal, and if after ten days from such written notice the violations complained of are not corrected, the same shall be a violation of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 10-32) 
Secs. 54-93-54-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LICENSE 

Sec. 54-121. - Required. 
    No person shall operate a food service establishment within the city without having first obtained a license, as required by this article, or after the license has been revoked by the council as provided in this division. 
(Code 1986, § 10-46) 
Sec. 54-122. - Issuance generally. 
    No new licenses shall be issued nor any licenses be renewed annually, as required by this article, without an application setting forth the location of the business, together with the name and address of the owner of the business, and in addition thereto a statement of the county board of health or its agents, recommending that the license be issued, together with the license fee or tax required by Chapter 22. 
(Code 1986, § 10-47) 
Sec. 54-123. - Filing application. 
    The application for a new business under this article shall be filed and the license issued prior to the time that the business is actually open for business, and all renewal licenses shall be filed and approved prior to March 1 of each year. 
(Code 1986, § 10-48) 
Sec. 54-124. - Revocation. 
    Should it be determined that any person has violated the provisions of this article and is wilfully continuing to violate the provisions of this article, the city marshal may cite such person requiring him to appear before the council to show cause why the license issued to such person should not be revoked, which hearing shall be held at the time and place specified in such notice, at which time the council shall cancel the license in question if the charges are found to be true and justify the cancellation. 
(Code 1986, § 10-49) 
Chapter 58 - HISTORIC PRESERVATION[1]

ARTICLE II. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-171 et seq. 

Sec. 58-31. - Definitions. 
    The definitions in O.C.G.A. § 44-10-22 shall be applicable to this article. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commission means the Milledgeville Historic Preservation Commission. 
    Exterior environmental features means all those aspects of the landscape or the development of the site which affect the historical character of the property. 
(Code 1986, § 15-31) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Definitions, O.C.G.A. § 44-10-22. 
Sec. 58-32. - Purpose. 
    In support and furtherance of its findings and determination that the historical, cultural, and esthetic heritage of the city is among its most valued and important assets and that the preservation of this heritage is essential to the promotion of the health, prosperity and general welfare of the people; in order to stimulate revitalization of the business districts and historic neighborhoods and to protect and enhance local historical and esthetic attractions to tourists and visitors and thereby promote and stimulate business; in order to encourage the acquisition by the city of conservation easements pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 44-10-1-44-10-8; in order to enhance the opportunities for federal tax relief of property owners under relevant provisions of the Tax Reform Act of 1976 allowing tax deductions for rehabilitation of certified historic structures (26 USC 191); the council hereby declares it to be the purpose and intent of this article to establish a uniform procedure for use in providing for the protection, enhancement, perpetuation, and use of places, districts, sites, buildings, structures, and works of art having a special historical, cultural, or aesthetic interest or value, in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 15-32) 
State Law reference- Legislative purpose and intent for Georgia Historic Preservation Act, O.C.G.A. § 44-10-21. 
Sec. 58-33. - Creation; position within city government; membership. 
(a)  Created. There is hereby created the Milledgeville Historic Preservation Commission. Commission members will have only advisory authority in recommending landmark and historic district designations. 
(b)  Position within city government. The commission shall be considered a part of the planning functions of the city. 
(c)  Members. The commission shall consist of nine residents of the city appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the aldermen who have demonstrated special interest, experience, or education in history or architecture. Members shall serve for three-year staggered terms. Members may not serve more than two consecutive terms. Members shall not receive a salary, although they may be reimbursed for expenses. 
(Code 1986, § 15-33) 
Sec. 58-34. - Powers. 
    The commission shall be authorized to: 
(1)  Prepare an inventory of all property within its respective historic preservation jurisdiction having the potential for designation as historic property; 
(2)  Recommend to the council specific places, districts, sites, buildings, structures, or works of art to be designated by ordinance as historic properties or historic districts; 
(3)  Review applications for certificates of appropriateness, and grant or deny the certificates of appropriateness in accordance with the provisions of this article; 
(4)  Recommend to the council that the designation of any place, district, site, building, structure, or work of art as a historic property or as a historic district be revoked or removed; 
(5)  Restore or preserve any historic properties acquired by the city; 
(6)  Promote the acquisition by the council of conservation easements in accordance with O.C.G.A. §§ 44-10-1-44-10-8; 
(7)  Conduct an educational program on historic properties located within its historic preservation jurisdiction; 
(8)  Make such investigations and studies of matters relating to historic preservation as the council or the commission itself may, from time to time, deem necessary or appropriate for the purposes of preserving historic resources; 
(9)  Seek out state and federal funds for historic preservation, and make recommendations to the council concerning the most appropriate use of any funds acquired; 
(10)  Consult with historic preservation experts in the division of historic preservation of the state department of natural resources or its successor and the Georgia Trust for Historic Preservation, Inc.; 
(11)  Submit to the division of historic preservation of the state department of natural resources or its successor a list of historic properties or historic districts designated as such pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 44-10-26; 
(12)  Perform historic preservation activities as the official agency of the city's historic preservation program; 
(13)  Receive donations, grants, funds, or gifts of historic property, and shall acquire and sell historic properties. The commission shall not obligate the council without prior consent; and 
(14)  Review and make comments to the state historic preservation office concerning the nomination of properties within its jurisdiction to the national register of historic places. 
(Code 1986, § 15-34) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 44-10-25; review of applications, procedure, approval, negotiations for acquisitions, variances, appeals, O.C.G.A. § 44-10-28. 
Sec. 58-35. - Rules of procedure. 
    The commission shall adopt rules for the transaction of its business and consideration of applications and shall provide for the time and place of regular meetings and for the calling of special meetings. The commission shall have the flexibility to adopt rules of procedure without amendment to this article. A quorum shall consist of a majority of the members. The latest edition of Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, shall determine the order of business at all meetings. 
(Code 1986, § 15-35) 
Sec. 58-36. - Funding. 
    The commission shall have the authority to accept donations and shall ensure that these funds do not displace appropriated governmental funds. 
(Code 1986, § 15-36) 
Sec. 58-37. - Records of meetings. 
    A public record shall be kept of the commission's resolutions, proceedings and actions. 
(Code 1986, § 15-37) 
Sec. 58-38. - Designation of historic districts and landmarks. 
(a)  Preliminary research. 
(1)  Survey of local historical resources. The commission shall have the authority to compile and collect information and collect surveys of historic resources within the city. 
(2)  Recommendations for designation. The commission shall present to the council nominations for historic districts and local landmarks. 
(3)  Report on proposed designations. The commission shall prepare formal reports when nominating historic districts or local landmarks. These reports shall be used to educate the community and to provide a permanent record of the designation. The report will follow guidelines for nominating structures to the national register of historic places (National Preservation Act of 1966), and shall consist of two parts: A physical description and a description of historic significance. This report will be submitted to the historic preservation section of the state department of natural resources. 
(b)  Designation of district. 
(1)  Boundaries. The boundaries of a historic district shall be specified on tax maps; these boundaries will be included in the separate ordinances designating local districts. Boundaries specified in legal notices shall coincide with the boundaries finally designated. Districts shall be shown on the official zoning map of the city. 
(2)  Evaluation of properties. Individual properties within historic districts shall be classified as: 
a.  Historic (more than 50 years old); 
b.  Nonhistoric (less than 50 years old, yet possessing architectural character); 
c.  Intrusions (structures less than 50 years old which do not contribute to the historical character of the district); 
d.  Existing zoning. This article is not a use ordinance, and the zoning ordinance of the city remains in effect until modified. 
(c)  Designation of a landmark. 
(1)  Criteria. A historic landmark is a structure, site, work of art, including the adjacent area necessary for the proper appreciation or use thereof, deemed worthy of preservation by reason of value to the city, the state or a local region, for one or more of the following reasons: 
a.  It is an outstanding example of a structure representative of its era; 
b.  It is one of the few remaining examples of past architectural style; 
c.  It is a place or structure associated with an event or person of historic or cultural significance to the city, the state or the region. 
(2)  Boundary description. The boundaries shall be clearly defined for individual properties on tax maps and located on the official zoning map. 
(d)  General matters. 
(1)  Application for designation. 
a.  Historic district. An historical society, neighborhood association, or group of property owners may apply for designation. 
b.  Landmark structure. An historical society or property owner may apply for designation. 
(2)  Hearings. The commission and the council shall hold a public hearing on the proposed ordinance for designation. Notice of the hearing shall be published at least three times in the principal newspaper of general circulation within the city, and written notice of the hearing shall be mailed by the commission to all owners and occupants of such properties. All the notices shall be published or mailed not less than ten nor more than 20 days prior to the date set for the public hearing. A letter sent via the United States mail to the last known owner of the property shall constitute legal notification to the owner under this article. Following the public hearing, the council may adopt the ordinance as prepared, adopt the ordinance with any amendments it deems necessary, or reject the proposal. 
(3)  Notification to property owners. Any ordinance designating any property or district as historic shall describe each property to be designated, shall set forth the name of the owner of the designated property, and shall require that a certificate of appropriateness be obtained from the commission prior to any material change in appearance of the designated property. 
(4)  District boundaries. Any ordinance designating any property or district as historic shall require that the designated property or district be shown on the official zoning map of the city and kept as a public record to provide notice of such designation. 
(5)  Contents of ordinance. Any ordinance designating any property or district as historic shall include a description of the boundaries of the property or district, shall list each property located therein, shall set forth the name of the owner of each property, and shall require that a certificate of appropriateness be obtained from the commission prior to any material change in appearance of any structure, site or work of art located within the designated property or district. 
(6)  Investigation and report by the commission. No ordinance designating any property as a historic property and no ordinance designating any district as a historic district nor any amendments thereto may be adopted by the council nor may any property be accepted or acquired as historic property by the council until the commission shall make or cause to be made an investigation and shall report on the historic, cultural, architectural, or esthetic significance of each place, district, site, building, structure, or work of art proposed for designation or acquisition. This report shall be submitted to the division of historic preservation of the state department of natural resources or its successor which will be allowed 30 days to prepare written comments concerning the report. 
(7)  Ordinance for designation announcement. A decision to accept or deny the ordinance for designation shall be made within 15 days following the public hearing and shall be in the form of a resolution to the council. 
(8)  Notification of adoption of ordinance. Within 30 days immediately following the adoption of the ordinance for designation, the owners and occupants of each designated historic property, and the owners and occupants of each structure, site, or work of art located within a designated historic district shall be given written notification of such designation by the council, which notice shall apprise such owners and occupants of the necessity of obtaining a certificate of appropriateness prior to undertaking any material change in the appearance of the historic property designated or within the historic district designated. 
(9)  Notification of other agencies. The commission shall notify all necessary agencies within the city of the ordinance for designation, including the local historical organization. 
(10)  Moratorium on alteration or demolition while ordinance is pending. If an ordinance for designation is being considered, the commission shall have the power to freeze the status of the involved property. 
(11)  Authority to amend or rescind designation. The commission has the authority to amend and/or rescind the designation if necessary. 
(Code 1986, § 15-38) 
State Law reference- Designation by ordinance of historic properties or districts, O.C.G.A. § 14-10-26. 
Sec. 58-39. - Application for certificate of appropriateness. 
(a)  Approval of alterations or new construction. After the designation by ordinance of a historic property or of a historic district, no material change in the appearance of the historic property, or of a structure, site or work of art within such historic district, shall be made or be permitted to be made by the owner or occupant thereof, unless or until application for a certificate of appropriateness has been submitted to and approved by the commission. Such application shall be accompanied by such drawings, photographs or plans as may be required by the commission. 
(b)  Approval of new construction. The commission shall issue certificates of appropriateness for new structures to be constructed within designated historic districts. These structures shall conform in design, scale, building materials, setback, and landscaping to the character of the district specified in the commission's design guidelines. 
(c)  Guidelines; criteria. When considering applications for certificates of appropriateness to existing buildings, the secretary of the interior's Standards of Rehabilitation shall be used as a guideline along with any other criteria adopted by the commission. 
(d)  Plans. An application for certificate of appropriateness shall be accompanied by such drawings, photographs, or plans as may be required by the commission. 
(e)  Reaction to application. 
(1)  The commission shall approve the application and issue a certificate of appropriateness if it finds that the proposed material change in the appearance would not have a substantial adverse effect on the esthetic, historical, or architectural significance and value of the historic property or the historic district. In making this determination, the commission shall consider, in addition to any other pertinent factors, the historical and architectural value and significance, architectural style, general design arrangement, texture, and material of the architectural features involved, and the relationship thereof to the exterior architectural style, and pertinent features of the other structures in the immediate neighborhood. 
(2)  The commission shall deny a certificate of appropriateness if it finds that the proposed material change in appearance would have substantial adverse effects on the esthetic, historic, or architectural significance and value of the historic property or the historic district. 
(f)  Notice; hearing. At least seven days prior to review of an application for a certificate of appropriateness, the commission shall take such action as may reasonably be required to inform the owners of any property likely to be affected materially by reason of the application, and shall give the applicant and such owners an opportunity to be heard. In cases where the commission deems it necessary, it may hold a public hearing concerning the application. 
(g)  Certificate of appropriateness. The commission shall approve the application and issue a certificate of appropriateness if it finds that the proposed material change in appearance would not have a substantial adverse effect on the esthetic, historical, or architectural significance and value of the historic property or the historic district. In making this determination, the commission shall consider, in addition to any other pertinent factors, the historical and architectural value and significance; architectural style; general design, arrangement, texture, and material of the architectural features involved; and the relationship thereof to the exterior architectural style and pertinent features of other structures in the immediate neighborhood. 
(h)  Interior alterations. In its review of applications for certificates of appropriateness, the commission shall not consider interior arrangement or uses having no effect on exterior architectural features. 
(i)  Technical advice. When dealing with difficult technical questions, the commission shall have the power to seek expert advice. 
(j)  Deadline for approval or rejection. 
(1)  The commission shall approve or reject an application for a certificate of appropriateness within not more than 45 days after the filing thereof by the owner or occupant of a historic property, or of a structure, site, or work of art located within a historic district. Evidence of approval shall be by a certificate of appropriateness issued by the commission. 
(2)  The failure of the commission to act within the 45-day period shall constitute approval, and no other evidence of approval shall be needed. 
(k)  Rejection of application. 
(1)  If the commission rejects an application, it shall state its reasons for doing so and shall transmit a record of such action and the reasons therefor, in writing, to the applicant. The commission may suggest alternative courses of action it thinks proper if it disapproves of the application submitted. The applicant, if he so desires, may make modifications to the plans and may resubmit the application at any time after doing so. 
(2)  In cases where the application covers a material change in the appearance of a structure which would require the issuance of a building permit, the rejection of the application for a certificate of appropriateness by the commission shall be binding upon the building official or other administrative officer charged with issuing building permits, and, in such a case, no building permit shall be issued. It shall be the responsibility of the commission to provide written notice to the building official, or such other administrative officer charged with issuing building permits, of the commission's rejection of the application for a certificate of appropriateness. 
(l)  Undue hardship. Where, by reason of unusual circumstances, the strict application of any provision of this article would result in an exceptional practical difficulty or undue hardship upon any owner of any specific property, the commission, in passing upon applications, shall have the power to vary or modify strict adherence to the provisions or to interpret the meaning of the provisions, so as to relieve such difficulty or hardship; provided, however, that such variance, modification, or interpretation shall remain in harmony with the general purpose and intent of the provisions, so that the architectural or historical integrity, or character of the property, shall be conserved and substantial justice done. In granting variances, the commission may impose such reasonable and additional stipulations and conditions as will, in its judgment, best fulfill the purpose of this article. An undue hardship shall be a situation not of the person's own making, which is: 
(1)  A problem unique to a specific property; or 
(2)  In order to comply with this article, the person will be in conflict with another ordinance of the city. 
(m)  Conformance with certificate. Work not in accordance with an issued certificate of appropriateness shall be halted before it is completed. 
(n)  Construction not commenced. A certificate of appropriateness shall become void unless construction is commenced within six months of the date of issuance. Certificates of appropriateness shall be issued for a period of 18 months and are renewable. 
(o)  Recording of applications. The commission shall keep a public record of all applications for certificates of appropriateness, and of all its proceedings. 
(p)  Acquisition of property. The commission may, where such action is authorized by the council and is reasonably necessary or appropriate for the preservation of a unique historic property, enter into negotiations with the owner for the acquisition by gift, purchase, exchange, or otherwise, of the property or any interest therein. 
(q)  Appeals. Any person adversely affected by any determination made by the commission relative to the issuance or denial of a certificate of appropriateness may appeal such determination to the council; the appeal must be applied for within 15 days after notification is sent. The council may approve, modify, or reject the determination made by the commission, if the council finds that the commission abused its discretion in reaching its decision. Appeals from decisions of the council made pursuant to the Georgia Historic Preservation Act, O.C.G.A. § 44-10-20 et seq., may be taken to the superior court of the county, in the manner provided by law, for appeals from a conviction for municipal or county ordinance violations. 
(Code 1986, § 15-39) 
State Law reference- Certificate of appropriateness, O.C.G.A. § 44-10-27 et seq.; records management programs for local governments, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-99. 
Sec. 58-40. - Demolition or relocation applications. 
(a)  Authority to comment. The commission shall have the authority to comment on any request for a permit to demolish or relocate a structure within an historic district, or classified as an historic landmark. 
(b)  Reaction to application. The commission shall have the authority to deny demolition or relocation permits within its jurisdiction. 
(c)  Considerations of predemolition plans. A public hearing shall be scheduled for each application for demolition or relocation. This hearing shall be scheduled prior to the delay period specified. 
(d)  Considerations of postdemolition plans. The commission shall not grant demolition permission or relocation permission without reviewing at the same time the plans for the building that would replace the structure. 
(e)  Demolition or relocation criteria. Upon receipt of an application for a certificate of appropriateness for demolition or relocation, the commission shall make a determination, supported by a written report, whether one or more of the following criteria are met: 
(1)  The structure is of such interest or quality that it would reasonably meet national, state, or local criteria for designation as an historic or architectural landmark. 
(2)  The structure is of such unusual or uncommon design, texture or materials that it could not be reproduced or be reproduced only with great difficulty and expense. 
(3)  Retention of the structure would aid substantially in preserving and protecting a structure which meets criterion (1) or (2). 
Where the commission determines that one or more of these criteria are met, no certificate of appropriateness shall be issued and the application shall be denied. 
(Code 1986, § 15-40) 
Sec. 58-41. - Maintenance of historic property. 
(a)  Ordinary repair. Ordinary maintenance or repair of any exterior architectural feature in or on an historic property, that does not involve a material change in design, material or outer appearance thereof, is excluded from review. 
(b)  Building codes. Nothing in this article shall be construed as to exempt property owners from complying with existing city or county building codes, nor to prevent any property owner from making any use of his property not prohibited by other statutes, ordinances, or regulations. 
(Code 1986, § 15-41) 
Chapter 62 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes:

Charter reference- Enforcement of peace, order and good government, § 2; power of city to remove garbage, trash, filth, nuisances, § 7; criminal jurisdiction over state law violations, § 38; offenses, § 43. 
Cross reference- Courts, ch. 34; traffic and vehicles, ch. 86.

Sec. 62-1. - Possession of alcoholic beverage for illegal sale. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to have or keep on hand in any place, house, stand, booth, wagon, automobile or on the person for illegal sale within the city, any malt beverages, distilled spirits or wines, or any mixture of such beverages which, if drunk to excess, will produce intoxication. 
(Code 1986, § 14-1) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6. 
State Law reference- Unlawful possession, etc., of alcoholic beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-27. 
Sec. 62-2. - Leaving cellar doors open. 
    Merchants shall keep their cellar doors in an upright position, when open at all, else be subject to a fine as set out in section 1-6 of this Code. 
(Code 1986, § 14-2) 
Sec. 62-3. - Congregating at fire. 
    It shall be unlawful for any persons to congregate within the streets or alleys of the city within a distance of 500 feet of a fire, and all persons within such area shall, upon request or direction of the mayor, the members of the council, the fire chief, assistant fire chief or a police officer, vacate that portion of the streets or alleys thereof as may lie within 500 feet of such fire. This section shall not apply to those persons engaged in fighting the fire under the direction of the fire department. 
(Code 1986, § 14-3) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 46. 
Sec. 62-4. - Damaging public property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is not authorized to do so to destroy or deface any public building or room or portion of such building or room. 
(b)  Authorized persons under subsection (a) of this section shall include the following under proper circumstances: Construction, repair and demolition personnel and firefighters. 
(Code 1986, § 14-4) 
State Law reference- Criminal damage to property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-22 et seq. 
Sec. 62-5. - Disorderly conduct. 
(a)  "Disorderly conduct" shall mean the commission of such words, acts and conduct upon public property, upon private property that is licensed by the city to conduct business or to provide services to the general public, or within the curtilage of any private residence not his own other than by invitation of the owner or lawful occupant, which under ordinary circumstances will naturally tend to disturb the public peace, tranquility or decorum, or shock the public sense of morality. Any person who engages in an act of disorderly conduct shall be guilty of an offense against the city. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the following specific acts and conduct shall be deemed a violation of this section: 
(1)  Fighting by two or more persons to the disturbance of the public tranquility or decorum; 
(2)  Use of obscene, vulgar, opprobrious or abusive language, without provocation, which by its very utterance tends to incite an immediate breach of the peace, that is to say, words which as matter of common knowledge and under ordinary circumstances will, when used to another person in the presence of the speaker, tend to provoke violent resentment, that is, words commonly called "fighting words"; 
(3)  Being and appearing in an intoxicated condition which is outwardly made manifest by boisterousness, by indecent condition or act, or by loud, vulgar, profane, opprobrious, abusive or unbecoming language, which by its very utterance tends to incite an immediate breach of the peace; 
(4)  Obstruction of any sidewalk, passage or parking area in such a way as to render it impassable without reasonable inconvenience or hazard and the failure or refusal to remove such obstruction upon being lawfully commanded to do so by a police officer; 
(5)  Engaging in boisterous, noisy, drunken or carousing acts, after receiving oral warning from a police officer that such activities have caused complaint or disturbance of the neighborhood or of orderly citizens. 
(c)  Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prevent the peaceful assembly of citizens in a lawful manner, the free exercise of protected speech, nor shall the mere possibility of disorder justify the exclusion of persons otherwise entitled to be present. 
(d)  Any person charged with a violation of this section shall have the right, upon written demand filed with the clerk of the municipal court, to a jury trial, upon a finding by the municipal court that probable cause exists to bind the case over to the appropriate state court. 
(Code 1986, § 14-5) 
State Law reference- Offenses against public order, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-30 et seq. 
Sec. 62-6. - Disturbing divine worship. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb in any manner a congregation of persons lawfully assembled for divine service. 
(Code 1986, § 14-6) 
State Law reference- Vandalism to a place of worship, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-26. 
Sec. 62-7. - Discharging firearms. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fire or discharge guns, pistols, rifles and other firearms, including, but not limited to, air rifles and pellet guns, within the limits of the city. 
(b)  This section is not intended to prohibit the discharging of firearms when the same is done in a bona fide effort to protect person or property. 
(Code 1986, § 14-8) 
State Law reference- Discharge of firearms, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-103 et seq.; use of force in defense of self or others, O.C.G.A. § 16-3-21. 
Sec. 62-8. - Possession of dangerous weapons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have, possess or carry upon the streets, alleys, sidewalks or in any public place in the city any of the following implements unless same are securely wrapped so as not to be readily available for harmful use: 
(1)  Any knife which has a blade which opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring or other device in the handle, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than two inches; 
(2)  Any knife which has any obstruction or other device of any kind which holds the blade partly open, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than two inches; 
(3)  Any knife of any kind, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than three inches. This is intended to include all knives such as butcher knives and/or knives which do not close and any type knife with the blade open; 
(4)  Any razor or razor blade; or 
(5)  Any ice pick or similar device having a sharp point, except this shall not apply to any person delivering ice. 
(Code 1986, § 14-9) 
State Law reference- Possession of dangerous weapons, etc., O.C.G.A. § 16-11-120 et seq.; carrying and possession of firearms, etc., O.C.G.A. § 16-11-126 et seq. 
Sec. 62-9. - Gambling generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for two or more persons to assemble within the limits of the city for the purpose of playing and betting for money, or other thing of value, at any game played with cards, dice or balls or for the purpose of playing and betting for money, or other thing of value, at any table of whatever name, kind or description, for gaming, or for the purpose of betting at any game of nine pins, or any other number of pins, or at any billiard or pool table. 
(Code 1986, § 14-10) 
State Law reference- Gambling and related offenses, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-20 et seq. 
Sec. 62-10. - Lotteries; number game. 
    It shall be unlawful for two or more persons to assemble for the purpose of aiding or carrying on a lottery known as the "number game." It shall also be a violation of this section for two or more persons to contact each other, or one another, in any way whatsoever for the purpose of carrying on a lottery known as the "number game." It shall be a violation of this section for two or more persons to agree or conspire for the purpose of aiding or carrying on a lottery known as the "number game." It shall be a violation of this section for any person to have in his possession a piece of paper, ticket or a certificate containing or representing a lottery ticket or number, or anything representing a chance, which is used in carrying on a lottery known as the "number game." It shall be a violation of this section for any person to deliver to another person a certificate, piece of paper, or ticket containing or representing a lottery ticket or number, or anything representing a chance, which is used in carrying on a lottery known as the "number game." It shall be a violation for any person to collect money from another for the purpose of carrying on a lottery known as the "number game." It shall be a violation of this section for any person to do any act, directly or indirectly, to aid another person in carrying on a lottery known as the "number game." It shall be unlawful for any person to accept money from another to use for the purpose of carrying on a lottery known as the "number game." This section shall not apply to any lawful activity relating to the Georgia Lottery for Education Act, O.C.G.A. § 50-27-1 et seq., or any other legally authorized lottery conducted in this state or another state. 
(Code 1986, § 14-14) 
State Law reference- Advertisement or solicitation for participation in lotteries, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-27. 
Sec. 62-11. - Nuisances. 
(a)  Defined. Any noise, or any act, or any condition, or anything, or any engine, or any machine, or any machinery which tends to injure the health, comfort or convenience of the inhabitants of the city, or tends to disturb the citizens of the community or neighborhood, in which such noise, act, condition, thing, engine, machine, machinery, exists or is operated, or which tends to work hurt, inconvenience, or damage to another is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and shall be abated as provided in this section. 
(b)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to create, conduct, operate or maintain a nuisance within the limits of the city. 
(c)  Citizen's petition. Any citizen of the city having knowledge of the existence of a nuisance within the city, and desiring the abatement of the same, shall file with the clerk and treasurer his petition, setting out the alleged nuisance, its location, and the person responsible for the nuisance, or upon whose premises it exists. 
(d)  Service of process. Upon such petition being filed with the clerk and treasurer, the clerk and treasurer shall issue a process or subpoena requiring the persons named in such petition to appear in the municipal court, to answer the petition, and a copy of the petition, process or subpoena shall be served upon each such person or defendant at least two days prior to the date of the session of the municipal court at which the trial is to be had. 
(e)  Order of abatement; summary removal; levy of costs. After trial, if the evidence shall disclose the existence of a nuisance as charged, the court shall render its judgment requiring the abatement thereof, and if such nuisance is not removed or abated by the defendant within such time as may be fixed by such judgment, which shall in no case exceed 20 days, it shall be the duty of the marshal, or chief of police, or police officer to remove or abate the same summarily. In that event the court shall ascertain the expense properly incurred by the marshal, chief of police, or police officer, and shall render judgment against the defendant for such amount, which judgment shall be collected by execution, issued by the clerk and treasurer. 
(f)  Abatement on order of council. The council may, in any case, direct the marshal, chief of police, or police officer to proceed in behalf of the city in the abatement of any nuisance, in which event all proceedings shall be had as provided in the foregoing subsections, except the process or subpoena shall be sued out in the name of the council, but the marshal, chief of police, or police officer shall not be disqualified from serving process or executing the judgment of the court on account of any official connection with such proceedings. 
(g)  Additional remedies. The court trying the issue shall, in addition to the right to order the abatement of the nuisance, be authorized to impose a fine or sentence according to the provisions set out in section 1-6. 
(Code 1986, § 14-15) 
State Law reference- Abatement of nuisances in cities, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5. 
Sec. 62-12. - Posting signs on poles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place election campaign posters, signs and advertisements: 
(1)  Within the right-of-way of any public streets, roads or highways; 
(2)  On any public property or building; 
(3)  On any private property unless the owner thereof has given permission to place such election campaign posters, signs and advertisements on such property; or 
(4)  On any property if the placement of such election campaign posters, signs and advertisements conflicts with any zoning laws or ordinances. 
(Code 1986, § 14-16) 
Sec. 62-13. - Covering wells. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have or maintain within the limits of the city any uncovered, unused well. All unused wells shall be securely covered, in an airtight manner, with plank, metal or concrete. A well not regularly used for a period of one month shall be deemed an unused well within the meaning of this section. 
(Code 1986, § 14-17) 
State Law reference- Abatement of hazard from abandoned well or hole, O.C.G.A. § 44-1-14. 
Sec. 62-14. - Illegal drugs. 
(a)  Definition. The term "knowingly," as used in this section, is defined as having actual or constructive knowledge which a reasonable person would have, acquire or determine from the use of his physical senses. 
(b)  Unlawful to be present where used or kept, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to be present: 
(1)  In any building or on any premises at any location in the city where illegal drugs are being used or kept; or 
(2)  In any vehicle, at any location in the city, wherein illegal drugs are being used or kept. 
(c)  Dispersal of illegal assemblies. The chief of police may declare unlawful and order the dispersion of any assembly or gathering of persons at any location in the city wherein illegal drugs are being used, sold or distributed; and it shall be unlawful for any person to fail or to refuse to immediately disperse upon being ordered to do so, as authorized in this section. 
(d)  Violations. A violation of any provision of this section shall constitute an offense pursuant to this section. 
(Code 1986, § 14-21) 
State Law reference- Controlled substances, O.C.G.A. § 16-13-1 et seq. 
Sec. 62-15. - Use of city property by shows, itinerants. 
    No show shall be allowed on any city property. All itinerants are barred from using such property as campgrounds or for other purposes; such property shall be used for park purposes only. 
(Code 1986, § 14-22) 
Charter reference- City owned property, § 66 et seq. 
State Law reference- Parks, historic areas, memorials, recreation, O.C.G.A. § 12-3-1 et seq.; local recreation systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq. 
Sec. 62-16. - Entering, remaining in all city parks after posted hours. 
    City owned parks shall be opened to the public one-half hour before sunrise and one-half hour after sunset of each day. It shall be unlawful for any person to enter or remain in the parks before or after the above stated time period. Notices shall be posted informing patrons of such regulations. 
(Code 1986, § 14-23; Ord. No. O-0305-015, 5-13-2003) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-0305-015, adopted May 13, 2003, changed the title of section 62-16 from "Entering, remaining in Central Park after dark" to "Entering, remaining in all city parks after posted hours." The historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Sec. 62-17. - Unauthorized person on premises of licensed retail sales car business and/or body shop business. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to be on the premises of a licensed retail sales car business and/or licensed body shop business on any day between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. if: 
(1)  Such unauthorized person have previously been warned by written citation issued by a law enforcement officer that their presence on the premises violates the provisions of this section; and 
(2)  The premises of the licensed retail sales car business and/or licensed body shop business is identified by at least one sign located at each entrance to the premises, and one sign located at the approximate midpoint of each boundary of the premises which does not have an entrance way. Each such sign shall contain the following information in easy-to-read printing: 
NOTICE 
In accordance with the "Code of Ordinances, City of Milledgeville, Georgia," it shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to be on the premises of (name of business) between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
Violators will be prosecuted and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine: 
a.  Not to exceed $200.00 for the first such offense; 
b.  Not to exceed $400.00 for the second such offense; and 
c.  Not to exceed $600.00 and/or six months imprisonment for the third or subsequent such offense. 
(b)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Unauthorized person means any person who has not received express permission of the owner or an authorized agent of the owner to be on such premises during the times prohibited by this section. 
(2)  Licensed retail car sales business means any business whose dominant activity is the retailing of new and/or used motorized vehicles to the general public, and who have a valid current business license issued by the city. 
(3)  Licensed body shop business means any business whose dominant business activity is the repair and restoration of damaged and/or wrecked motorized vehicles who have a valid and current business license issued by the city. 
(c)  A person who violates this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine: 
(1)  Not to exceed $200.00 for the first such offense; 
(2)  Not to exceed $400.00 for the second such offense; and 
(3)  Not to exceed $600.00 and/or six months imprisonment for the third or subsequent such offense. 
(Code 1986, § 14-24) 
Sec. 62-18. - Unlawful use of services; injury to and interference with property of utilities. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Intentionally and without authority and permission from the owner thereof to injure or destroy any meter, pipe, conduit, wire, pole, lamp, manhole cover, fireplug or any accessories thereto belonging to the city, the Milledgeville Water Works or any other public or private utility (called the owner) engaged in the manufacture or sale of electricity, gas, water, telephone, television, the furnishing of sanitary sewer service, or other public services without the intent to pay the fair cost of repair or replacement thereof; 
(2)  Intentionally and without authority and permission from the owner utilize any such service or consume any such product with intent to not pay the regular charge therefor to the owner, but with the intent to deprive the owner thereof; 
OFFENSES 
(3)  Intentionally and without authority prevent a meter from registering the quantity such service or product supplied with the intent to deprive the owner of its regular charge therefor; 
(4)  In any way interfere with the proper action of any such owner with intent to divert any service or product so as to deprive the owner of the regular charge therefor; 
(5)  Otherwise intentionally and without authority use or cause to be used, without the consent of such owner, any product or service furnished, manufactured, sold or distributed by such owner with intent to deprive the owner of its regular charge therefor. 
(b)  Proof that a person performed any of the acts set forth in subsection (a) of this section or proof that a person knowingly received the benefits of such acts or proof that any of the acts specified in subsection (a) of this section were done on the premises in possession of a person, with that person's knowledge, shall be prima faci evidence that such a person is responsible for such prohibited acts. 
(c)  Every person convicted in the municipal court of a violation of any provision of subsection (a) or (b) of this section shall be punished for a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. of 6-13-1995) 
State Law reference- Damaging, injuring or interfering with property of public utility companies, municipalities or political subdivisions, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25. 
Sec. 62-19. - Noise control. 
(a)  Purpose. This section is enacted to protect, preserve and promote the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city through the control of noise. It is the intent of this section to establish standards that will reduce excessive community noises, which are harmful and otherwise detrimental to individuals and to the community in the enjoyment of life and property and in the conduct of business. 
(b)  Sound measurement standards for law enforcement personnel. For the purposes of this section, "plainly audible" shall mean any sound emanating from the specific sound-producing sources set forth below which can be heard from the distances set forth below, using the following sound measurement standards: Measurement shall be by the auditory senses of a person standing at a distance no less than the required minimum distance from the source of the sound. For music and other noise, words and phrases need not be discernable. For music and other noise, bass reverberations are included. 
(c)  Prohibited conduct. 
(1)  Restrictions of 300 feet for 7:00 a.m. through 11:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and 7:00 a.m. through 12:00 midnight on Friday and Saturday. 
a.  Mechanical sound-making devices. It is unlawful for any person or persons to play, use, operate, or permit to be played, used, or operated any radio receiving device, television, stereo, musical instrument, phonograph sound amplifier or other machines or devices for the producing, reproducing or amplifying of sound and/or noise at such a volume and in such a manner so as to create, or cause to be created, any noises or sounds which are plainly audible at a distance of 300 feet or more from the building, structure or vehicle, or in the case of real property, beyond the property limits, in which it is located, whichever is farthest, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on Friday and Saturday. 
b.  Human-produced sounds. It is unlawful for any person or persons to yell, shout, hoot, whistle, or sing on the public streets or sidewalks or on private property so as to create, or cause to be created, any noises or sounds which are plainly audible at a distance of 300 feet or more from the place, building, structure, or in the case of real property, beyond the property limits, in which the person is located, whichever is farthest, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on Friday and Saturday. 
c.  Commercial advertising. It is unlawful for any person or persons to use, operate, or permit to be used or operated any radio receiving device, musical instrument, phonograph, loud speaker, sound amplifier or other machine or device for the production or reproduction of sound which is cast upon the public streets or other public property for the purpose of commercial advertising or which serves to attract the attention of the public to any building, structure or vehicle in such a manner so as to create, or cause to be created, any noises or sounds which are plainly audible at a distance of 300 feet or more from the source of the sound cast upon the public streets or other public property or from the building, structure, or in the case of real property, beyond the property limits, in which it is located, whichever is farthest, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12 midnight on Friday and Saturday. 
d.  Party noise. It is unlawful for any person or persons in charge of a party or other social event that occurs on any private property to allow that party or social event to produce noise in such a manner that such noise is plainly audible at a distance of 300 feet or more from the building or structure from which the noise is emanating or in the case of real property, beyond the property limits, on which the party or social event is located, whichever is farthest, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12 midnight on Friday and Saturday. For the purposes of this subsection, a "person in charge of a party or other social event" shall mean any adult person who resides in or on the premises involved in such party or social event and is present at such party or social event. For the purposes of this subsection, "noise" shall mean the same sounds, or any combination thereof, as described in subsections a. or b. above. 
(2)  Restrictions of 100 feet for 11:00 p.m. through 7:00 a.m. Sunday through Thursday and 12:00 midnight through 7:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday. 
a.  Mechanical sound-making devices. It is unlawful for any person or persons to play, use, operate, or permit to be played, used, or operated any radio receiving device, television, stereo, musical instrument, phonograph sound amplifier or other machines or devices for the producing, reproducing or amplifying of sound and/or noise at such a volume and in such a manner so as to create, or cause to be created, any noises or sounds which are plainly audible at a distance of 100 feet or more from the building, structure, or motor vehicle or in the case of real property, beyond the property limits, in which it is located, whichever is farthest, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday. 
b.  Human-produced sound. It is unlawful for any person or persons to yell, shout, hoot, whistle, or sing on the public streets or sidewalks or on private property so as to create, or cause to be created, any noises or sounds which are plainly audible at a distance of 100 feet or more from the place on public streets and sidewalks, or in the case of private real property, beyond the property limits, on which the person is located, whichever is farthest, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday. 
c.  Commercial advertising. It is unlawful for any person or persons to use, operate, or permit to be used or operated any radio receiving device, musical instrument, phonograph, loud speaker, sound amplifier or other machine or device for the production or reproduction of sound which is cast upon the public streets or other public property for the purpose of commercial advertising or which serves to attract the attention of the public to any building, structure or vehicle in such a manner so as to create, or cause to be created, any noises or sounds which are plainly audible at a distance of 100 feet or more from the source of the sound cast upon the public streets or other public property or from the building, structure, or in the case of real property, beyond the property limits, in which it is located, whichever is farthest, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday. 
d.  Party noise. It is unlawful for any person or persons in charge of a party or other social event that occurs on any private property to allow that party or event to produce noise in such a manner so as to such noise is plainly audible at a distance of 100 feet or more from the building or structure from which the party noise is emanating or in the case of real property, beyond the property limits, on which the party or social event is located, whichever is farthest, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday. For the purposes of this subsection, a "person in charge of a party or other social event" shall mean any adult person who resides in or on the premises involved in such party or social event and is present at such party or social event. For the purposes of this subsection, "noise" shall mean the same sounds, or any combination thereof, as described in subsections a. or b. above. 
(3)  Restrictions for areas within apartments, condominiums, townhouses, duplexes, or other such residential dwelling units. Except for persons within commercial enterprises that have an adjoining property line or boundary with a residential dwelling unit, it is unlawful for any person to make, continue, or cause to be made or continued any noise in such a manner as to be plainly audible to any other person a distance of five feet beyond the adjoining property line wall or boundary of any apartment, condominium, townhouse, duplex, or other such residential dwelling units with adjoining points of contact. 
For the purposes of this subsection, "noise" shall mean human-produced sounds of yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling, singing, or mechanically-produced sounds made by radio-receiving device, television, stereo, musical instrument, phonograph sound amplifier or other machines or devices for the producing, reproducing, or amplifying of sound, or any combination thereof. 
For the purposes of this subsection, "property line or boundary" shall mean an imaginary line drawn through the points of contact of (1) adjoining apartments, condominiums, townhouses, duplexes or other such residential dwelling units with adjoining points owned, rented, or leased by different persons, or (2) adjoining common areas or adjoining exterior walls. Said property line or boundary includes all points of a plane formed by projecting the property line or boundary including the ceiling, the floor, and the walls. 
(4)  Exclusions. The prohibitions of this section shall not apply to the following: 
a.  Noises and/or sounds caused to be made by manufacturing, governmental, construction or commercial entities in the normal course of their business; 
b.  Noises and/or sounds emanating from any official Georgia College and State University event on Georgia College and State University property, any official Georgia Military College event on Georgia Military College property, or any official Baldwin County School District event on Baldwin County School District property, provided, however, the sponsors of any event that is covered by this subsection that including commercial entertainment shall be required to comply with the provisions of subsection (d); 
c.  Noises and/or sounds that are permitted by a registered outdoor event pursuant to subsection (d); provided, however, that the producer or coordinator of the special event must comply with the terms, restrictions and conditions of the outdoor event registration; 
d.  Noises or sounds made by loud or noisy dogs, which noises or sounds are controlled by section 14-48; 
e.  Noises or sounds made by wireless telecommunication facilities. 
f.  Noises or sounds caused by industrial uses in the light industrial (LI) and heavy industrial (HI) zones established in the city's land development code. 
g.  Sound volumes produced by radio, tape player, or other mechanical sound making device or instrument from within a motor vehicle on a street or highway, which sound is controlled by the O.C.G.A. § 40-6-14; or 
h.  Noises or sounds made by law enforcement and other public safety officials performing their public functions. 
(5)  Time restrictions on use of landscape maintenance motorized devices such as leaf blowers, lawn mowers, or chain saws. It is unlawful for any person to use or operate any noise-generating, motorized landscape maintenance devices, including but not limited to leaf blowers, lawn mowers, or chain saws, within any residential zoning district or in areas within 300 feet of any residential zoning district from 9:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. 
(d)  Registration of outdoor entertainment events. Registration is required of all outdoor entertainment events that have commercial entertainment and/or electronic amplification. Registration of the event must be 72 hours prior to the event, and must be by the person or persons responsible for the event. Registration is to be with the city police department, Monday through Friday, from 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., on an application specified by the chief of police and shall include the organization sponsoring the event, the location, the date and time of the event, and security provisions. Registration shall not be accepted for events that include the hours between 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Sunday through Thursday, and between 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday mornings. Failure to register may result in a fine, forfeiture of the right of future registrations, or both. Registration does not exempt the person or persons registering the event from ensuring that the event complies with the requirements of this section. Failure to register shall be a violation of this subsection. 
(e)  Penalties. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided by section 1-8. 
(Ord. No. O-0608-021, 8-8-2006) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-0608-021, adopted August 8, 2006, amended section 62-19 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, section 62-19 pertained to amplified noise, and derived from Ord. No. O-0305-017, adopted May 14, 2008. 
Cross reference- Disorderly conduct generally, § 62-5.

ARTICLE II. - PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-171 et seq. 

Sec. 66-31. - Established; purpose. 
    In order to guide and accomplish a coordinated and harmonious development of the city which will be in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote the public health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, the Milledgeville Planning and Zoning Commission is hereby created. 
(Code 1986, § 15-16) 
Sec. 66-32. - Membership; vacancy; removal; compensation. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall consist of five members appointed by the council. The members shall serve for five-year staggered terms to commence in January 1 following appointment. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the council, which shall also have the authority to remove any member for cause, on written charges, after a public hearing. All members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. 
(Code 1986, § 15-17) 
Sec. 66-33. - Organization, rules, staff, finances. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall elect its chairperson from among its members. The term of the chairperson shall be one year with eligibility for reelection. The commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or employee of the city or the county. The commission shall make its own rules of procedure and determine its time of meeting. All meetings of the commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public as required by law, and all records of the commission shall be a public record. The commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work and may contract with the state department of community affairs and with city planners and other consultants for such services as it may require. The expenditures of the commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the council. 
(Code 1986, § 15-18) 
State Law reference- Open and public meetings, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1 et seq. 
Sec. 66-34. - Powers and duties. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall have all the powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in the zoning ordinance or other legal authority. 
(Code 1986, § 15-19) 
Chapter 70 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 70-1-70-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - JUNKYARDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 86. 
State Law reference- Secondary metals recyclers, O.C.G.A. § 10-1-350 et seq.; control of junkyards, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-240 et seq.; removal of junked motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4; junk dealers, O.C.G.A. § 43-22-1 et seq.; scrap metal processors, O.C.G.A. § 43-43-1 et seq. 

Sec. 70-31. - Definition. 
    As used in this article, a "junkyard" is an establishment or place of business which is maintained, operated or used for storing, keeping, buying or selling junk, or for the maintenance or operation of an automobile graveyard. This definition includes scrap metal processors, recycling stations, auto wrecking yards, salvage yards, scrapyards, auto recycling yards, used auto parts yards and temporary storage of automobile bodies or parts awaiting disposal as a normal part of a business operation when the business will continually have like materials located on the premises. The definition includes garbage dumps and sanitary landfills. 
(Code 1986, § 12-231) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 70-32. - Intent. 
    This article is not intended to authorize any violation of state law. 
(Code 1986, § 12-232) 
Sec. 70-33. - Visibility. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, maintain or operate a junkyard within the city which is visible from a publicly dedicated street or highway, except as provided in this article. 
(Code 1986, § 12-233) 
Sec. 70-34. - Screening. 
    Effective screening from view shall be accomplished by using natural and/or manmade materials, relocating junk on the site or using a combination of these methods. Screens shall have an effective height of eight feet, and no junk shall be stacked so as to be visible above this height. Entrances and exits shall likewise be screened in other than normal business hours. Screens shall be maintained to be effective as long as junk is stored on the site. Alternative types of screening are as follows: 
(1)  Use of plant material. Planting of trees, shrubs, etc., of a sufficient size and density to provide yearround effective screening. Plants shall be selected to complement the existing highway and adjacent land use environmental conditions; 
(2)  Earth grading. Construction of earth mounds, graded, shaped and planted to a natural appearance, to block visibility; 
(3)  Architectural barrier. Utilization of fences, walls or other structural elements; 
(4)  Relocation on site. The relocation of scrap inventory on the site to utilize an existing natural screen or screenable portion of the site; or 
(5)  A combination of the screenings outlined in this section. 
(Code 1986, § 12-234) 
Sec. 70-35. - Future junkyards. 
    Except as provided in section 70-36, all junkyards shall be located only in areas zoned industrial according to the official zoning ordinance of the city. Screening requirements shall continue to apply to junkyards in industrial areas. 
(Code 1986, § 12-235) 
Sec. 70-36. - Existing junkyards. 
    Junkyards in existence on December 13, 1977 which are not in an area zoned industrial according to the official zoning ordinance of the city, and which are declared by the council to be an attractive nuisance to children and others in the area, shall be appropriately fenced or walled to discourage entry. Entrances and exits shall be locked during hours other than normal business hours. Existing junkyards which are not in an area zoned industrial, and which cease to actively be in business for a period of 90 days, shall not be reestablished after such time period. 
(Code 1986, § 12-236) 
Sec. 70-37. - Unlawful junkyards. 
    Any operating or abandoned junkyard found not to conform to this article shall be removed or obliterated by the owner within 60 days of notice by the council. Upon failure by the owner to do so, the council may have the junkyard removed or obliterated and submit by registered or certified mail a statement of expenses for payment by the owner. If payment is not received by the city within 30 days, the council may take legal proceedings to recover the expense. 
(Code 1986, § 12-237) 
Chapter 74 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power of city to remove garbage, trash, filth, nuisances, § 7; collection of debts due city, § 56; powers and duties of planning commission, § 79. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 42; health and sanitation, ch. 54; utilities, ch. 90. 
State Constitution reference- Municipal solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III. 
State Law reference- Dumping garbage in caves or sinkholes, O.C.G.A. § 12-4-145; waste management, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-1 et seq.; litter, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-40 et seq.; securing loads on vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-21. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 74-1. - Pemises to be cleared of unhealthful or unsightly matter. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant or tenant of any property or premises, whether vacant or occupied, or for any person, either as owner or in control of any vacant lot, to permit to remain thereon any weeds or grasses exceeding ten inches in height, filth, trash, noxious growth, filthy or standing water or other unhealthful or unsightly matter. 
(Code 1986, § 9-1) 
Sec. 74-2. - Remedies for failure to keep premises clean. 
(a)  If any owner, tenant or other person in possession or control of any premises within the city limits shall fail or refuse to remove therefrom the matter described in section 74-1, within five days after having been notified so to do by the city, the owner, tenant or other person in possession or control of such premises, whether vacant or otherwise, shall, upon conviction of violation of the provisions of such section, be subject to fine and imprisonment, all or both in the discretion of the court, as set out in section 1-8. 
(b)  In case of failure or refusal of any person to comply with the provisions of section 74-1, and as cumulative of the remedy provided by prosecution of such offenders, the city, through its proper authority, shall have the right to enter upon and remove from any such lands or premises, all weeds growing or standing thereon and all other growth of like character, thereby placing such premises in sanitary and sightly condition, and to charge the cost of removal to the owner or owners of any such premises or vacant lots, and the clerk and treasurer shall have full, ample and complete authority to issue therefor execution in the name of the city, which execution shall issue and be levied as executions for taxes in the city are issued and levied. Such execution shall issue and constitute a lien upon the property so cleaned and against the owner or owners thereof, provided a detailed, itemized statement of the cost of such work shall be attached to and form a part of such execution, and provided further that no execution shall issue against any land owner unless he shall have been served in person with written notice at least five days before such work is commenced by the city, and provided further that if such land owner is a nonresident, the written notice must have been mailed to him, or to his last known address, at least ten days prior to beginning the work by the city. 
(c)  The owner against whom execution may have issued, as provided in this article, shall have the right to contest the execution, or the amount thereof, in the same manner as provided by the laws of the state governing illegalities and claims where executions are levied. 
(Code 1986, § 9-2) 
State Law reference- Tax executions, O.C.G.A. § 48-3-1 et seq. 
Secs. 74-3-74-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 

Sec. 74-41. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Class I. Single-family dwelling, i.e., a building or part thereof used exclusively as living quarters for any number of individuals living together as a single housekeeping unit; and small businesses which produce not more than one cubic yard of garbage weekly. 
    Class II. Small businesses which produce more than one cubic yard and not more than four cubic yards of garbage weekly. 
    Class III. Medium-sized businesses which produce more than four and not more than ten cubic yards of garbage weekly. 
    Class IV. Large businesses which produce more than ten and not more than 20 cubic yards of garbage weekly. 
    Class V. Very large businesses which produce more than 20 and not more than 80 cubic yards of garbage weekly. 
    Garbage means the ordinary accumulation of refuse incident to the operation of a household or place of business, and shall not be construed to include brick, stone, lumber, wood, boxes or building debris. 
(Code 1986, § 9-16) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-42. - Accumulation of garbage declared nuisance. 
    Any person allowing garbage to accumulate by failing to comply with the payment of the fees and charges fixed and assessed under this article shall be liable to the full provisions of the law applicable to nuisance and upon the property owned by such person being declared a nuisance by reason of any unauthorized accumulation of garbage on any premises shall be subject to being tried for a nuisance as a violation of the terms of this article and upon conviction thereof in the municipal court of city shall be punished as provided in section 1-6. 
(Code 1986, § 9-17) 
Sec. 74-43. - Charges for garbage disposal. 
    There are hereby adopted the following schedules of reasonable rates, tolls, fees and charges to be made against owners, occupants, tenants and lessees of buildings and premises for the service by the sanitation department of collection, removal and disposal of garbage within the city. The following rates and charges to be made and the amount collected for each monthly period, or portion thereof, shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  a.  Residential buildings and premises. The collection and removal of garbage from houses, buildings and premises used for residential purposes shall be made not less than once a week. The fair and reasonable rate for this residential service shall be $14.50 per container per month, or any portion thereof, for each single-family dwelling. 
b.  Apartment buildings and other multi-family premises. The collection and removal of garbage from apartment complexes, townhomes, duplexes or any buildings and premises used for multifamily residential purposes shall be made not less than once a week. The fair and reasonable rate for this residential service shall be $14.50 per dwelling unit. 
(2)  Business and commercial buildings and premises. The collection and removal of garbage from business and commercial buildings and premises shall be as often as needed, commensurate with the needs presented by the volume of garbage produced by such business and commercial buildings and premises. The fair and reasonable rates for this business and commercial service per month, or any portion thereof, shall be according to the following schedule:
