State Constitution reference- Outdoor advertising devices adjacent to certain highways, Ga. Const. art. III, § VI, ¶ II(a)(6). 
State Law reference- Obstruction of streets, sidewalks, etc., O.C.G.A. §§ 16-11-43, 32-6-1, 36-30-10; eminent domain, O.C.G.A. tit. 22; highways, bridges and ferries, O.C.G.A. tit. 32; municipal street systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq.; outdoor advertising adjacent to certain highways, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-70 et seq.; streets and sidewalks generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; street improvements, O.C.G.A. § 36-39-1 et seq.; bonds for public contractors, O.C.G.A. § 36-82-100 et seq.; bonds for nonresident contractors, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-32. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Driving upon streets, sidewalks, alleys closed to traffic. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a motor vehicle, wagon or other conveyance over and upon the streets, sidewalks and alleys of the city while the streets, sidewalks and alleys are being paved, repaired or constructed, or where sewer or water connections are being made, where such street, sidewalk or alley has been closed to traffic. 
(b)  Where a street has been closed to traffic for any purpose, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive a motor vehicle, wagon or other conveyance over and upon the sidewalks of the street so closed to traffic. 
(Code 1986, § 16-1) 
Sec. 78-2. - Lights on excavations. 
    At the place of every excavation in the streets or sidewalks there shall be placed red lights at night, by the person having such excavations. 
(Code 1986, § 16-2) 
Sec. 78-3. - Interference with barricades. 
    Where signs, lights, or obstructions have been placed in the streets of the city for the purpose of directing traffic or closing streets to traffic, it shall be unlawful for any person to remove, injure or destroy the signs, lights or obstructions. 
(Code 1986, § 16-3) 
Sec. 78-4. - Encroachment on sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to encroach upon any sidewalk in the city by constructing or erecting upon any sidewalk any building or part thereof, any cellar, cellar door, or part thereof. 
(Code 1986, § 16-4) 
Sec. 78-5. - Use of sidewalks by merchants for display purposes. 
    Merchants shall be allowed to utilize three feet of space on the sidewalk extending from the building and the entire width of their building in front for displaying merchandise. 
(Code 1986, § 16-5) 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 
Sec. 78-6. - View at intersections. 
    The city may move any shrub or other obstacle on city property deemed to be a traffic hazard. 
(Code 1986, § 16-6) 
Sec. 78-7. - Washing vehicles; allowing wastes to run upon sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to wash or clean any automobile or other motor vehicle in the streets, sidewalks or public alleys of the city, and it shall be unlawful for any person to wash or clean any automobile or other motor vehicle in such close proximity to the sidewalks of the city that the water, grease, or oil used or wasted in such washing or cleaning shall run on, upon, or across the sidewalks. 
(Code 1986, § 16-7) 
Sec. 78-8. - House numbers required. 
    Every residence, storehouse, shop, and other places of business within the corporate limits of the city shall be numbered as provided by the building official. 
(Code 1986, § 16-8) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 
Secs. 78-9-78-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREET CUTS 

Sec. 78-41. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public utility company means a corporation under the jurisdiction of the Georgia Public Service Commission which holds a franchise from the city. 
    Street means any area designated by the city as a public street, either owned by the city or dedicated by private persons and designated as a street. 
(Code 1986, § 16-21) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 78-42. - Disturbing surface or subsurface of streets. 
    No person shall dig or excavate in any street within the city or install anything under the surface of such street, or do any work which requires the removal or breaking of the surface or subsurface of any street except as specifically authorized by this article. 
(Code 1986, § 16-22) 
Sec. 78-43. - Water excavations, installations, repairs. 
(a)  The city shall have exclusive control and management of all water lines lying within the streets in the city and shall install, repair and maintain all of such lines and perform all necessary excavations, cuts, refilling and repaving connected with the installation and maintenance of such lines. No private person shall interfere with any water line within the city streets or disturb the surface or subsurface of such streets for the purpose of gaining access to such lines. 
(b)  The city shall alter, extend or stub-out water lines so as to make them available to any property within the city and shall perform all necessary excavations, cuts, refilling and repaving connected with the installation of such lines provided that the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The property owner, or a duly licensed plumber acting on his behalf, shall at a time not less than 48 hours prior to the commencement of the work applied for, file with the building official a written application, setting forth the need for such water service, the location of the property to be served, a sketch showing the relative locations of existing water and sewerage lines, and any paved street surface which must be disturbed in gaining access to such line. 
(2)  Such property owner, or a duly licensed plumber acting on his behalf, shall pay to the city at the time of the application the applicable fee. 
(3)  All work on water lines shall be performed by the city within the right-of-way lines of the streets, and it shall be the responsibility of the respective property owner to install and maintain all lines on his property in accordance with the city plumbing code. 
(4)  The city shall not be obligated to alter, extend or stub-out any water lines if in the opinion of the city engineer such lines would overload or otherwise damage existing water and sewerage mains or lines, would be in violation of the city plumbing code, or would otherwise not be in the best interest of the city property and the health and well being of its citizens. 
(Code 1986, § 16-23) 
Editor's note- The city's utility fees are on file in the office of the city clerk and treasurer. 
Sec. 78-44. - Sewer excavations, installations and repairs. 
(a)  Persons desiring to disturb the surface or subsurface of streets for the purpose of gaining access to sewer lines may do so upon compliance with the terms of this section. 
(b)  A person may obtain a permit to disturb the surface or subsurface of the streets for the purpose of gaining access to sewer lines upon meeting the following conditions: 
(1)  The applicant shall, at a time not less than 48 hours prior to the commencement of the work applied for, file with the building official a written application setting forth the character and location of such work to be done, the probable number of cubic yards of dirt to be removed, and the probable date of beginning and the completion of the work. 
(2)  The applicant shall, at the time of application, demonstrate to the satisfaction of the building official proof of a liability insurance policy in force during the period of the permit applied for, naming the city as beneficiary, and conditioned to pay on behalf of the city all sums which the city shall become legally obligated to pay as damages because of excavation or other work covered by such permit. Such liability policy shall have limits of liability of no less than $50,000.00 for property damage and $100,000.00 for personal injury. 
(3)  Permits under this section shall specify the location of the work to be done, the purpose of the work, the type and extent of excavation to be performed, the time allowed for full performance of the work and shall be signed by the city engineer. 
(4)  All permits issued by the city shall become void after the expiration of the allotted time designated in the permit, unless an extension is granted by the city engineer in writing. 
(5)  The applicant shall cut only such pavement as is necessary to the excavation applied for, and such cutting is to be done in straight, neat lines, with a saw, and so as to leave the edges of pavement vertical and square with the surface down to subgrade. 
(6)  No job in the city streets shall be begun by the applicant pursuant to the provisions of this article between the hours of 12:00 noon on Fridays and 9:00 a.m. on Mondays of each week, except in cases of extreme emergency. 
(7)  It shall be the duty of applicant to give written notice to the city engineer immediately upon completion of the work authorized by such permit. The applicant shall not refill or repave the excavation but shall guard it with sufficient barricades and flambeaus, flares, or lights until the city completes the refilling and repaving of the excavation. 
(8)  All applicants under this section shall be plumbers, duly licensed to do business within the city. 
(9)  Upon completing the refilling and repaving of each excavation the city engineer shall bill the applicant for the cost of such refilling and repaving, and the applicant shall be liable for such cost upon receipt of such bill. 
(10)  No permit shall be issued by the city engineer to any person who is indebted to the city for work already done in repairing excavated streets and pavements, until such person shall have discharged in full all such indebtedness. 
(11)  No excavation shall remain open for a period greater than eight hours, unless specifically authorized in writing by the city engineer in accordance with uniform city standards. 
(Code 1986, § 16-24) 
Sec. 78-45. - Street excavation by public utility company. 
(a)  A public utility company desiring to disturb the surface or subsurface of streets for the purpose of gaining access to its own main, conduit or utility may do so upon compliance with the terms of this section. 
(b)  The public utility company shall, at a time not less than 48 hours prior to the commencement of the work applied for, file with the building official a written application setting forth the character and location of such work to be done and the probable date of beginning and the completion of the work provided; however, in the event of any emergency in which a main, conduit or utility in or under any street breaks, bursts, or otherwise is in such condition as to immediately endanger the property, life, health or safety of any individual, the person owning or controlling such main, conduit or utility, without first applying for and obtaining an excavation permit under this article, shall immediately take proper emergency measures to cure or remedy the dangerous conditions for the protection of property, life, health and safety of individuals. However, such person owning or controlling such facility shall apply for an excavation permit not later than the end of the next succeeding day during which the city engineer's office is open for business. 
(c)  Permits under this section shall specify the location of the work to be done, the purpose of the work, the type and extent of excavation to be performed, and the time allowed for full performance of the work and shall be signed by the city engineer. 
(d)  All permits issued by the city shall become void after the expiration of the allotted time designated in the permit, unless an extension is granted by the city engineer in writing. 
(e)  No job in the city streets shall be begun by any person pursuant to the provisions of this section between the hours of 12:00 noon on Fridays and 9:00 a.m. on Mondays of each week, except in cases of extreme emergency. 
(f)  It shall be the duty of the applicant to refill such excavation according to the following specifications: 
(1)  Where the material taken from the trench is not satisfactory to the city engineer, suitable material, meeting the approval of the engineer, shall be procured, placed and compacted as provided in these specifications. 
(2)  Backfills shall be built up in layers and each layer shall be thoroughly compacted before beginning another layer. Layers may be three feet in depth if compaction is performed by a hydro hammer of design approved by the engineer. Whenever compaction by hand is done, it shall be in layers of not more than four inches in depth per layer, and the number of persons backfilling shall not exceed the number of persons ramming; the size and weight of the rams shall be approved by the engineer. Puddling will not be permitted, nor will frozen or wet material be placed in trenches. 
(3)  After compaction, the dry weight per cubic foot of any six-inch depth of backfill shall be at least 95 percent of the maximum laboratory dry weight per cubic foot as determined by American Association of State Highway Officials Method T-99. 
(g)  It shall be the duty of the applicant to give written notice to the city engineer immediately upon completion of each backfill. 
(1)  The applicant shall not repave the surface of the street but the city shall do so and bill the company monthly for all repaving costs; provided, however, the applicant may repave the excavation if requested in writing to do so by the city engineer. 
(h)  Applicant shall guard the excavation with necessary barricades, flambeaus, flares or lights until such time as traffic may be reasonably permitted thereon. 
(i)  By the acceptance of each permit the applicants under this section shall agree to save and keep harmless the city from any and all liability by reason of damage or injury to any persons or property whatsoever, on account of negligence of the applicant, its contractors or agents, in performing the work pursuant to such permit, provided the applicant shall have been notified in writing of any claim against the city on account thereof and shall have been given ample opportunity to defend the claim. 
(j)  No excavation shall remain open for a period greater than eight hours, unless specifically authorized in writing by the city engineer. 
(Code 1986, § 16-25) 
Secs. 78-46-78-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - UTILITY SYSTEMS GENERALLY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of council as to public utilities, § 70. 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 90. 

Sec. 78-81. - Application of article. 
(a)  This article and the regulations by it provided shall not have application to any single service connection extended, installed or otherwise made by any public utility unless the completion of such single service connection shall require the cutting or breaking of more than one square yard of surface area of any paved street, walkway, driveway or sidewalk in the city. 
(b)  All rights relating to the use of the streets, sidewalks, parkways, lanes and alleys of the city by or under any franchise granted by the city shall be deemed to be regulated by this article in the public interest. 
(Code 1986, § 16-41) 
Sec. 78-82. - Approval required for installation of facilities for public utility upon public property. 
    No line, pole, tower, wire, cable, conduit, piping or tubing, whether to be located and installed at ground level, overhead, or underground, and whether the same is an extension of any existing facility, an addition thereto, or a renewal, or a replacement thereof, forming or to form any part of the distribution or service system of any public utility, shall be located, placed, installed, or erected in, on, upon, over, across or under any of the streets, sidewalks, parkways, lanes or alleys in the city until and unless the owner or a qualified representative of the owner of the projected or proposed line or other facility shall have first obtained the written approval of and consent for the whole of the same from the city by and through its designated city engineer. 
(Code 1986, § 16-42) 
Sec. 78-83. - Restoration of street cuts, sod, involved in construction. 
    Should any proposal or project under this article include any work the execution of which shall require the cutting or breaking of any sidewalk, driveway, walkway or street paving, or the removal of any grass sod, in any of the streets, sidewalks, parkways, lanes or alleys in the city, the proposal or project shall not be approved and the execution thereof shall not be commenced until evidence satisfactory to the city engineer shall be submitted that the person applying for such consent and approval is ready, able and willing to immediately restore the surface of the area to be affected by such work to its appearance and condition existing prior to the doing of the work. 
(Code 1986, § 16-43) 
Sec. 78-84. - Liability of persons involved in construction. 
(a)  Any person who shall as an individual, officer, agent, contractor, workman, employee, or otherwise, do any of the acts or things specified in sections 16-42 and 16-43, or aid or take part in the doing of any of the same without the consent for and approval of such work having been first obtained in writing from the designated engineer of the city, shall be deemed in violation of this article. 
(b)  Every person, including owners, contractors, agents, firms, corporations, associations, servants, officers and employees who shall violate any of the provisions of this article and perform work at, about or upon, or otherwise take part in the performance of any work or project described in this article, for which no approval has been made in writing by the designated engineer of such city, shall be deemed in violation of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 16-44) 
Secs. 78-85-78-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARADES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 86. 

Sec. 78-121. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Assembly means a crowd or more than ten persons standing, congregated or assembled upon any sidewalks, streets or other public property in the city. 
    Demonstration and picketing shall be given their usual meaning, considering the context in which they are used in this article. 
    Parade means any procession, excepting funerals, containing 25 or more persons or five or more vehicles. 
(Code 1986, § 14-18) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 78-122. - Parade, assembly and demonstration-Permit. 
(a)  Any person desiring to stage a parade, demonstration or assembly, or engage in picketing, shall make application for a permit to the city not later than 4:00 p.m. on the day prior to the day that such proposed activity is intended to be staged or carried out. Such application shall be filed with the clerk and treasurer, who shall forward the application to the chief of police. Such permit shall be granted by the chief of police, but the chief of police shall be empowered to determine and reasonably restrict the time and duration of the proposed activity, the number of units or automobiles to be involved, the number of persons to participate in such activity, and the streets or locations where such activity shall be allowed, so as not to impair the safety and convenience of the public generally, after giving due consideration to the permit. In the absence of the chief of police, such duties and powers hereby delegated to the chief of police may be performed by the mayor or the city marshal. 
(b)  An application and permit shall be required for each such activity; provided, however, only one application and permit shall be required for each proposed parade, demonstration, assembly, or picketing site and course of picketing. 
(c)  All such activities shall be conducted under the supervision of the person making application for the permit, and shall be conducted in a peaceable and orderly manner in compliance with the laws and ordinances applicable thereto. 
(d)  In the conduct of such activities, no signs, shields or banners shall be placed or carried by any person upon the sidewalks of this city that extend beyond the width of the person's body or extend more than 24 inches above the person's head; and persons carrying any such signs, shields or banners shall be at least ten feet apart, shall not stand or loiter in front of any doorway, driveway or street intersection, and shall not interfere with the general flow of traffic, whether pedestrian or vehicular. 
(Code 1986, § 14-19) 
State Law reference- Labor organizations and labor relations, O.C.G.A. § 34-6-1 et seq.; operation of motor vehicles in parades, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-7. 
Sec. 78-123. - Same-Penalty. 
    Any person parading, holding demonstrations, picketing or assembling without first acquiring a permit as required by section 78-122 or any person violating any of the provisions of such section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1986, § 14-20) 
Chapter 82 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Taxation, § 49 et seq. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; finance, § 2-131 et seq.; possession of fully tax paid alcoholic beverages, § 6-3; case tax on distilled spirits, § 6-114; excise tax on sales of alcoholic beverages by the drink, § 6-261 et seq.; business license tax for financial institution, § 22-32; gross premium tax imposed on life insurance companies, § 22-74; gross premium tax on all other insurers, § 22-75. 
State Constitution reference- Taxation power of municipal governments, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV; development authorities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § VI, ¶ III. 
State Law reference- Revenue and taxation, O.C.G.A. tit. 48; development authorities, O.C.G.A. §§ 36-62-1 et seq., 48-5-350. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Sales and use tax. 
    A combination city-county local sales and use tax at the rate of one percent is hereby levied. 
(Code 1986, § 17-1) 
State Law reference- Joint county and municipal sales and use tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-8-80 et seq. 
Secs. 82-2-82-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HOTEL-MOTEL EXCISE TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Excise tax on rooms, lodgings and accommodation, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. 

Sec. 82-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except when the context clearly indicates a contrary meaning: 
    Due date means from the 20th day after the close of the monthly period for which tax is to be computed. 
    Guest room means a room occupied, or intended, arranged, or designed for occupancy, by one or more occupants for the purpose of living quarters or residential use. 
    Hotel means a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings, or accommodations are regularly furnished for value. 
    Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession, of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room. 
    Occupant means any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has the right to use or possess any room in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license, or use, or other agreement, or otherwise. 
    Operator means any person operating a hotel in this city including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises, the lessee, sublessee lender in possession, licensee, or any other person otherwise operating such hotel. 
    Permanent resident means any occupant as of a given date who has or shall have occupied or has or shall have the right of occupancy of any guest room in a hotel for more than ten consecutive days, or for five or more consecutive days if the occupant is a Georgia state or local government official or employee when traveling on official business. 
    Person means an individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint-stock company, corporation, nonprofit corporation or cooperative nonprofit membership, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, excepting the United States of America and any political subdivision thereof upon which the city is without power to impose the tax provided in this chapter. 
    Rent means the consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the operator to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. 
    Return means any return filed or required to be filed as provided in this article. 
(Code 1986, § 17-16) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-32. - Violations. 
    Any operator or other person who fails to register as required in this article, or who fails to furnish any return required to be made, or who fails or refuses to furnish a supplemental return or other data required by the clerk and treasurer, or who renders a false or fraudulent return, shall be deemed guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1986, § 17-17) 
Sec. 82-33. - Administration; enforcement. 
    The clerk and treasurer shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the collection of the tax imposed by this article, and in so doing shall have the following powers to: 
(1)  Examine, or authorize the examination of, the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment, and other facilities of any operator renting guest rooms to persons subject to the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the operator, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid; 
(2)  Require the filing of reports by any person or persons having in his or their possession or custody information relating to rentals of guest rooms which are subject to the tax levied in this article; and 
(3)  Allow a credit on any amount due and payable from persons who paid the tax levied in this article but who were erroneously or illegally subjected thereto. 
(Code 1986, § 17-18) 
Sec. 82-34. - Rate of levy; use of proceeds. 
    There is hereby set and levied an excise tax in the amount of eight percent of the rent and fees collected, for furnishing for value to the public any room or rooms, lodging or accommodations, by any person or legal entity in the corporate limits of the city operating a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings or accommodations are regularly furnished for value. Such rate is set and levied pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. and the local Act of the General Assembly (House Bill 776), and the proceeds of this tax shall be used in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50.2 and as set forth in the local Act (House Bill 776). 
(Code 1986, § 17-19; Ord. No. O-0905-008, 6-9-2009) 
Sec. 82-35. - Collection of tax by operator. 
    It shall be the duty of every operator of a hotel located within the city to collect the tax on occupants as imposed in this article. 
(Code 1986, § 17-20) 
Sec. 82-36. - Exemption. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, no tax shall be imposed under this article upon a permanent resident. 
(Code 1986, § 17-21) 
Sec. 82-37. - Registration of operator. 
(a)  Every person engaging in or about to engage in business as an operator of a hotel in his city shall register such business with the clerk and treasurer, on a form provided by him for such purpose. The registration shall set forth the name under which the operator transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of his place or places of business, and such other information as would facilitate the collection of the tax by the clerk and treasurer. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person; by a member or partner in case of ownership by an association or partnership; or by an officer in the case of ownership by a corporation. 
(b)  A separate registration shall be required for each place of business or operator. 
(Code 1986, § 17-22) 
Sec. 82-38. - Certificate of taxing authority. 
    Upon the registration of an operator under this article, the clerk and treasurer shall issue to such operator without charge a certificate of authority to collect the tax on occupants. Each certificate shall state the name and location of the business to which it relates. 
(Code 1986, § 17-23) 
Sec. 82-39. - Due date; report. 
    All taxes levied by this article shall be due and payable to the clerk and treasurer monthly on or before the 20th day of every month next succeeding each respective month in which such taxes are collected, and payment shall be accompanied by a return for the preceding monthly period showing the gross rent, rent from permanent residents, taxable rent, amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the period, and such other information as may be required by the clerk and treasurer. 
(Code 1986, § 17-24) 
Sec. 82-40. - Determination if no return made. 
    If any hotel operator fails to file a return as required under the provisions of this article, the clerk and treasurer shall make an estimate of the gross rentals of such operator which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period in which the operator failed to file the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the clerk and treasurer. 
(Code 1986, § 17-26) 
Sec. 82-41. - Notice of determination. 
    The clerk and treasurer or his designated representative shall give to the hotel operator written notice of his determination of the gross rentals. The notice may be served personally or by mail; if by mail such service shall be addressed to the operator at his address as it appears in the records of the clerk and treasurer. Service by mail is complete when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by the addressee. 
(Code 1986, § 17-27) 
Sec. 82-42. - Interest on amount found due. 
    The amount of the determination made under this article shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the 20th day of the month following the monthly period, for which the amount of any portion thereof should have been returned, until the date of payment. 
(Code 1986, § 17-28) 
Sec. 82-43. - Records. 
    Each hotel operator collecting a tax under the provisions of this article shall keep for a period of at least three years all records, receipts, invoices, and other pertinent papers setting forth the rental charged for each occupancy, the date or dates of occupancy, and such other information as the clerk and treasurer may require. 
(Code 1986, § 17-29) 
Sec. 82-44. - Action for collection. 
    At any time within three years after any tax or any portion of such tax required to be collected under this article becomes due and payable, the city attorney may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the city to collect such amount due, together with interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees, and other legal fees incident thereto. 
(Code 1986, § 17-30) 
Sec. 82-45. - Successors or assignees of operator. 
    If any hotel operator becomes liable for any amount required to be paid by this article and subsequent thereto sells his business or quits the business, the successors or assignees of such operator shall withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase price to cover such amount due. In the event such purchaser of the business fails to withhold the required amount, he shall become personally liable therefor to the extent of the purchase price. 
(Code 1986, § 17-31) 
Sec. 82-46. - Proceeds of tax. 
    The proceeds of this excise tax shall be used in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(3). 
(Ord. No. O-0610-028, 10-24-2006) 
Chapter 86 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power of city to regulate vehicles, § 60. 
Cross reference- Any ordinance prescribing traffic regulations for specific locations, such as prescribing speed limits, through streets, parking limitations, parking prohibitions, one-way traffic or limitations on loads of vehicles or loading zones, not inconsistent with such Code saved from repeal, § 1-7(12); self service motor fuel dispensing pumps, § 22-111 et seq.; courts, ch. 34; transportation routes for explosives, § 46-35; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 62; junkyards, § 70-31 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78; parades, § 78-121 et seq.; vehicles for hire, ch. 94. 
State Law reference- Uniform Rules of the Road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; powers of local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371 et seq.; abandoned motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 86-1. - State law-Adopted. 
    Pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372-40-6-376, the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1, and O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-1-40-6-346, the Uniform Rules of the Road, are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this city with like effect as if recited in this section. 
(Code 1986, § 13-1) 
Sec. 86-2. - Same-Violations. 
    Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of section 86-1 shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1986, § 13-2) 
Sec. 86-3. - Signs. 
    The council shall designate and install signs and other traffic control devices in the city except at locations where the state department of transportation has jurisdiction. 
(Code 1986, § 13-3) 
Sec. 86-4. - Temporary traffic rules. 
    In cases where the traffic upon the streets of the city may become congested, and upon the occasion of parades, theatrical entertainments and other public assemblages, when a large number of vehicles are assembled, the police may make temporary rules regulating the traffic in such congested districts, and any person who, after being warned of the temporary traffic regulation by a police officer, shall refuse to comply with such regulation, shall be liable to the punishment prescribed in section 1-8. 
(Code 1986, § 13-4) 
Sec. 86-5. - Trespass on college square. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle or trespass on foot on the square known as the Old Capitol Square occupied by the Georgia Military College and bounded on the north by Green Street, on the east by Elbert Street, on the south by Franklin Street and on the west by Wayne Street, unless the occupant of the vehicle or the pedestrian shall be on such square on business with the college, or attending some function taking place on such square to which the public is invited. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to the walk leading from the south gate of the Old Capitol Square to Wayne Street near the Episcopal church. 
(Code 1986, § 13-5) 
Sec. 86-6. - Speed breakers on streets. 
(a)  No speed breakers, risers, rumble strips or other such structures shall be placed or maintained on any streets within the limits of the city unless authorized by proper resolution of the council. Said resolution shall identify the particular street or streets upon which the speed breakers, risers, rumble strips or other such structures shall be placed, and shall identify the specific type of structure that is being authorized for installation upon said street or streets. 
(b)  Upon the installation of speed breakers, risers, rumble strips or other such structures in accordance with this section, the city shall cause to be erected proper signage and other street markings that are adequate to warn motorists of the installation of the particular speed control device authorized by this section. 
(Code 1986, § 13-6; Ord. No. O-0608-023, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 86-7. - Criminal trespass by motor vehicle. 
(a)  In accordance with the authority granted in O.C.G.A. § 40-6-252(c), the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-252(a) are hereby adopted. 
(b)  Any person violating this section shall be subject to a monetary fine not to exceed: 
(1)  $50.00 for the first such violation; 
(2)  $100.00 for the second such violation; 
(3)  $150.00 for the third or any subsequent violation. 
(Code 1986, § 13-7; Ord. of 6-20-1989) 
Secs. 86-8-86-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Operation of vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-40 et seq. 

Sec. 86-41. - Driving vehicle without consent of owner. 
    No person shall operate an automobile, motorcycle or similar vehicle upon any of the streets, lanes or alleys of the city without the consent of the owner. 
(Code 1986, § 13-41) 
State Law reference- Offenses involving theft, O.C.G.A. § 16-8-1 et seq. 
Sec. 86-42. - Driving through processions. 
(a)  No vehicle shall cut or run through any parade or funeral procession, except as directed by a police officer. Drivers of all vehicles shall observe and obey the signals of police officers at the intersections of streets. 
(b)  The first sentence of subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles. 
(Code 1986, § 13-42) 
Sec. 86-43. - Driving over fire department equipment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle on, over or against any fire engine, fire pump or other firefighting apparatus belonging to the city. 
(Code 1986, § 13-43) 
Sec. 86-44. - Distance from fire. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle on the streets or alleys of the city, who may be within a distance of 500 feet of a fire at the time of its outbreak, to permit such vehicle to remain in such street or alley, but shall immediately drive the vehicle to a point more than 500 feet from such fire. 
(Code 1986, § 13-44) 
Sec. 86-45. - Automobiles, motorcycles, bicycles and skateboards on sidewalks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, ride, park or lay down any automobile, motorcycle, bicycle or skateboard upon the sidewalks on the streets listed in this section with the exception of any merchant who has bicycles or skateboards for sale: 
(1)  Clark Street, between Greene Street and Montgomery Street. 
(2)  Liberty Street, between Greene Street and Hancock Street. 
(3)  Wilkinson Street, between Greene Street and Montgomery Street. 
(4)  Wayne Street, between Greene Street and Montgomery Street. 
(5)  Jefferson Street, between Greene Street and Montgomery Street. 
(6)  Greene Street, between Jefferson Street and Clark Street. 
(7)  Hancock Street, between Jefferson Street and Clark Street. 
(8)  McIntosh Street, between Jefferson Street and Wilkinson Street. 
(9)  Montgomery Street, between Jefferson Street and Clark Street. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the police department to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(c)  Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, on conviction in the municipal court, be punished in the discretion of the municipal court judge but not in excess of the provisions as provided in the Charter of the city and the acts amending the Charter and the ordinances passed thereunder. 
(Code 1986, § 13-46; Ord. No. O-0704-002, 4-24-2007) 
Secs. 86-46-86-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing and parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200 et seq.; powers of local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-81. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the police department to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1986, § 13-61) 
Sec. 86-82. - General restriction. 
(a)  Vehicles of any type, including but not limited to buses, trucks, cars, automobiles, lawn mowers, tractors, farm machinery, boat trailers, utility type trailers or any type trailer to be drawn by any type motorized or nonmotorized vehicle or vehicles, or any and all parts and appurtenances to any type vehicle whether farm, commercial or domestic, shall not be left stopped, standing, parked or stored upon any right-of-way of any streets, alleyways, lanes, cul-de-sacs or any land designated as public property at any time, unless properly zoned, marked, posted and time permitted. All other times they are strictly prohibited. 
(b)  Items listed in this section shall be moved within eight hours after notification; otherwise they shall be impounded in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1986, § 13-62) 
Sec. 86-83. - Loading and unloading. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to back any vehicle to the street curb unless for the purpose of actually loading or unloading, or to keep such vehicle backed to such curb longer than is necessary to actually load or unload. When loading or unloading, all vehicles shall stand diagonally and near the righthand curb, unless it is possible for such vehicle to stand parallel to the righthand curb. No vehicle shall stand abreast of another. 
(Code 1986, § 13-63) 
Sec. 86-84. - Loading zones designated by signs. 
    When appropriate signs are erected giving notice thereof, the areas so marked shall be loading zones. 
(Code 1986, § 13-64) 
Sec. 86-85. - Obstructing traffic; egress of previously parked vehicles. 
(a)  No vehicle shall be parked so as to obstruct traffic. 
(b)  No vehicle shall be parked or stopped in such a position as to prevent the convenient movement of another vehicle already parked. 
(Code 1986, § 13-65) 
Charter reference- Power of city to prohibit the obstruction of streets, § 7; removal of obstructions, § 8. 
Sec. 86-86. - Parking time in alleys. 
    No vehicle of any description shall be left standing for a longer time than 30 minutes in any of the alleys of the city. 
(Code 1986, § 13-66) 
Sec. 86-87. - Parking beyond curb line. 
    The parking of vehicles of any type where any of the wheels of such vehicle, when parked, extend onto the established curb lines of the streets of the city, or onto that area between the established curb lines and the extremities of the street right-of-way, is hereby prohibited. 
(Code 1986, § 13-67) 
Sec. 86-88. - No parking areas to be designated by signs. 
    Where signs are erected prohibiting parking upon certain sections of the streets and/or the curbs are painted yellow, parking upon the streets so marked yellow or appropriate signs erected, parking at all times shall be prohibited unless otherwise indicated. 
(Code 1986, § 13-68; Ord. No. O-0508-029, 8-9-2005) 
Sec. 86-89. - Limitation on use of parking spaces. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park on the streets, alleys or public parks of the city, any automobile, truck or motor vehicle, except such as are being used in vehicular traffic in the city, or to park any automobile, truck or motor vehicle in the streets, alleys or public parks of the city, there to be exhibited, offered for sale, held for sale, held for rent, held for repair, held for storage, repaired or sold. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to taxicabs operating in the city while in the charge of the driver thereof. 
(Code 1986, § 13-69) 
Sec. 86-90. - Controlled vehicle parking in residential areas. 
(a)  Definitions. Whenever in this section the following words are used, they shall, unless the context requires otherwise, be deemed to have the following meanings: 
    Controlled parking residential zones means a contiguous area containing streets or parts thereof upon which there may be designated restricted residential parking by the city. 
    Guest means one who is a recipient of hospitality at the home of another. 
    Resident means one who makes his home in a particular place with ownership. 
    Tenant means one who pays rent to occupy property owned by another for a stated period of time. 
(b)  Privileges and restrictions on controlled parking residential zones. 
(1)  Where parking prohibited. A residential parking zone shall not authorize the resident, tenant or guest to stop, stand or park a motor vehicle in such places where the stopping, standing or parking of a motor vehicle is prohibited or set aside for specific types of vehicles, nor exempt the resident, tenant or guest from the observance of any traffic regulation within the controlled residential area. 
(2)  Use of on-street parking; nonresidents. No person other than residents, tenants or authorized guests of the controlled parking residential area shall park on streets properly marked as a residential parking zone. 
(3)  The following streets have been designated as controlled vehicle parking: 
a.  Liberty Street from Greene Street to Franklin Street. 
b.  Greene Street from Columbia Street to Tattnall Street (north side only). 
c.  Greene Street from Clarke Street to Wilkinson Street (south side only). 
d.  Jackson Street from Hancock Street to Greene Street. 
e.  North Columbia Street from Montgomery Street to Hancock Street. 
f.  North Clarke Street from Montgomery Street to Thomas Street. 
g.  Washington Street from Wayne Street to Clarke Street. 
h.  South Wilkinson Street from Greene Street to Franklin Street. 
i.  North Jefferson Street from Hancock Street to Montgomery Street. 
(4)  Any person violating this section shall be subject to a monetary fine not to exceed: 
a.  Fifty dollars for the first such violation; 
b.  One hundred dollars for the second such violation; 
c.  One hundred fifty dollars for the third or any subsequent violation. 
(5)  Administrative regulations. The police department shall have the authority to develop and implement administrative regulations for the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-0507-019, 7-26-2005) 
Sec. 86-91. - Residential permitted parking. 
(a)  Definitions. Whenever in this section the following words are used, they shall, unless the context requires otherwise, be deemed to have the following meanings: 
    Controlled parking residential zones means a contiguous area containing streets or parts thereof upon which there may be designated restricted residential parking by the city. 
    Guest means one who is a recipient of hospitality at the home of another. 
    Resident means one who makes his home in a particular place with ownership. 
    Residential parking permit means a permit issued hereunder for the privilege of parking on a street designated as a "controlled parking residential area." 
    Residential permitted parking only means a special area for the restricted parking of residents and guests on a street designated as being within a controlled parking residential area. 
    Tenant means one who pays rent to occupy property owned by another for a stated period of time. 
(b)  Privileges and restrictions on residential permitted parking only. 
(1)  Permit bestows privileges and restrictions on residential parking permits. The holder of a residential parking permit shall be permitted to stand or park a motor vehicle displaying the permit and operated by him or her in a designated residential controlled parking area. While a vehicle for which a residential parking permit has been issued is so parked, such a permit shall be prominently displayed in the bottom drivers side corner of the front windshield of the vehicle. 
(2)  Where parking prohibited. A residential parking permit shall not authorize the holder thereof to stand or park a motor vehicle in such places where the stopping, standing or parking of a motor vehicle is prohibited or set aside for specific types of vehicles, nor exempt the holder from the observance of any traffic regulation within the controlled residential area. 
(3)  Where parking permitted. A residential parking permit shall permit such residents/tenants to park in a designated street for such permit. 
(4)  Use by persons other than permitted regulated. No person other than the permittee named thereon shall use the residential parking permit or display it on a vehicle operated or parked, and any such use or display by a person other than the permittee shall constitute a violation of this chapter by the permittee and by the person who so used or displayed such parking permit. Bona fide visitors of permittee shall be issued a guest permit with permission of the permittee. 
(5)  False representation. It shall constitute a violation of this chapter for any person to falsely represent himself as eligible for a residential parking permit and to furnish any false information in an application in order to obtain a residential parking permit. 
(6)  Revocation of permit. The city is authorized to revoke the residential parking permit for any permittee found to be in violation of this chapter and upon written notification thereof, the permittee shall surrender such to the city. Failure, when requested, to surrender a residential parking permit so revoked shall constitute a violation of this chapter. 
(7)  Administrative regulations. The police department shall have the authority to develop and implement administrative regulations for the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-0507-020, 7-26-2005) 
Secs. 86-92-86-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TIME LIMITS 

Sec. 86-111. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Operator means every individual who shall operate a vehicle as the owner thereof, or as the agent, employee or permittee of the owner, or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
    Park or parking means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, upon a street otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of, and while actually engaged in, receiving or discharging passengers or loading or unloading merchandise or in obedience to traffic regulations, signs or signals, or an involuntary stopping of the vehicle by reason of causes beyond the control of the operator of the vehicle. 
    Parking space means any space within the parking zone which is duly designated for the parking of a single vehicle by lines painted or otherwise durably marked on the curb or on the surface of the street adjacent to or adjoining the parking space. 
    Vehicle means any device, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported upon a highway, except a device which is operated upon rails or tracks. 
(Code 1986, § 13-86) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 86-112. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of, or operated by such person to be parked overtime, or beyond the period of legal parking time established for any parking zone. 
(2)  Park any vehicle across any line or marking of a parking space or in such position that the vehicle shall not be entirely within the area designated by such lines or markings. 
(3)  Park any vehicle on the right-of-way of State Route 29 (US 441) except in the case of an emergency. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate or fail to comply with any of the provisions of this division, or who shall counsel, aid or abet any such violation or failure to comply, shall be deemed guilty of an offense and shall be punished as provided for in section 1-8. 
(Code 1986, § 13-87; Ord. of 9-12-1995; Ord. No. O-0509-036, 10-11-2005) 
Sec. 86-113. - Reservation of powers. 
    Nothing in this division shall be construed as prohibiting the city from providing for bus stops, for taxicab stands and other matters of a similar nature, including the loading or unloading of trucks, vans or other commercial vehicles. 
(Code 1986, § 13-88) 
Sec. 86-114. - Parking zones. 
    There are established, as designated by ordinance, parking zones as follows: 
(1)  Twelve-minute parking zones; 
(2)  Thirty-minute parking zones; 
(3)  Two-hour parking zones; and 
(4)  Four-hour parking zones. 
(Code 1986, § 13-89) 
Sec. 86-115. - Designation of parking spaces and time zones. 
    Parking spaces shall be designated as marked off in city parking zones. The chief of police may mark off in such zones additional parking spaces and may alter any parking space now existing or marked off, in such manner as he deems advisable to accomplish the purposes of this article. At each space so marked off it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in such a way that such vehicle shall not be entirely within the limits of the space so designated. The chief of police or city marshal, with consent from the city manager, may change or designate any parking space or zone for the overall safety of the community. 
(Code 1986, § 13-90; Ord. No. O-0509-036, 10-11-2005) 
Sec. 86-116. - Parking time limits. 
    The parking time limits shall be in effect in city parking zones every day between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., except Sundays and holidays; provided, however, that within the meaning of this article the term "holidays" shall include only legal holidays under the laws of Georgia. 
(Code 1986, § 13-91; Ord. No. O-0509-036, 10-11-2005) 
State Law reference- Public and legal holidays, O.C.G.A. § 1-4-1. 
Sec. 86-117. - Railroad trains blocking streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for the directing officer or the operator of any railroad train to direct the operation of or to operate the same in such a manner as to prevent the use of or to obstruct any street, road highway or public road crossing for purposes of travel located within the city limits for a period of time longer than six minutes, except that this provision shall not apply to trains or cars disabled or emergencies, unavoidable accidents or circumstance beyond the control of the railroad company. 
(Ord. No. O-0512-042, 12-27-2005) 
Secs. 86-118-86-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- When police officers may remove vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-206. 

Sec. 86-141. - Other prosecution. 
    The impounding of a vehicle shall not prevent or preclude prosecution for violations of the penal provisions of this chapter or any other ordinance relating to traffic. 
(Code 1986, § 13-106) 
Sec. 86-142. - Authority to establish pound. 
    The chief of police may create a vehicle pound to which automobiles and other vehicles may be removed by police officers in the manner provided in this division. Such pound shall be located at such places as may be designated by the chief of police. 
(Code 1986, § 13-107) 
Sec. 86-143. - Impoundment of vehicle. 
    Whenever any vehicle shall be found parked in any place within the city where parking is not permitted at that time, or whenever any vehicle is found parked in violation of the terms of this chapter or any other ordinance relating to traffic, such vehicle may be wheel locked or removed, and conveyed by any member of the police department by means of towing the vehicle, or otherwise, to a vehicle pound. 
(Code 1986, § 13-108; Ord. No. O-0509-036, 10-11-2005) 
Sec. 86-144. - Records. 
(a)  The officer impounding a vehicle under this division shall immediately report the fact of such impounding, together with any other information which will definitely identify the vehicle, to the chief of police, who shall cause a permanent record to be made thereof, a copy of which will be filed with the clerk and treasurer. 
(b)  The record kept by the chief of police of all vehicles committed to the pound shall include the names and addresses of the owners of the vehicles, the numbers of their state license tags and the nature and circumstances of each violation, as well as the disposition of each case, and shall account for all fees collected under this division. The chief of police shall pay the fees in to the city treasury, taking a receipt therefor. 
(Code 1986, § 13-109) 
Sec. 86-145. - Release of impounded vehicle. 
    Any person claiming a vehicle impounded under this division shall produce evidence of his identity and ownership or right of possession to the chief of police and pay to such officer the fees and cost for removal and storage, for which a receipt shall be given and an order issued to the officer in charge of the pound to discharge the vehicle and to deliver the vehicle to such person. Thereupon, the impounded vehicle shall be surrendered by the officer in charge thereof, who shall take a receipt for such impounded vehicle. Such receipt shall definitely identify the vehicle and shall become a permanent record of the police department. A copy of such receipt shall be delivered to the clerk and treasurer. 
(Code 1986, § 13-110) 
Sec. 86-146. - Protest and bond. 
(a)  In case a protest is made against the payment of any impounding or storage fee under this division, the chief of police may authorize the person in charge of the impounded vehicle to discharge the vehicle. 
(b)  The person making the protest shall be charged with violation of this chapter or other traffic ordinances and shall make bond for his appearance and trial before the municipal court judge. Thereupon, the chief of police shall authorize the person in charge of the impounded vehicle to deliver it to such person. If such person is convicted of violating this chapter or other traffic ordinances by the judge, in addition to other costs the judge shall assess as cost the fees for removal and storage which have accumulated in connection with the impounding of such vehicle. 
(Code 1986, § 13-111) 
Sec. 86-147. - Sale of impounded vehicle. 
    When any vehicle is left on the streets and it becomes necessary for the police department to take charge of it in order to preserve the safety of travel on the streets, and the police department does take charge of it and removes it and places it in storage, and it is not claimed for as long as 30 days, the chief of police shall sell it. He shall place an advertisement in the newspaper in which the city's advertisements are published, describing the vehicle and giving such information about it as will put the owner or other person having knowledge thereof in possession of the facts, stating that the vehicle is in his possession or control and that, at the expiration of ten days, it will be exposed for sale, at the place where the vehicle is kept or stored, and the proceeds turned in to the city treasury. At the time named, the chief shall proceed to the place where the vehicle is stored and expose it for sale and sell it to the highest bidder for cash. A record shall be kept of such sale showing each vehicle sold, with a description corresponding to the advertisement, the name of the purchaser and the amount received therefor. The chief of police shall turn the proceeds of the sale in to the clerk and treasurer, keeping such record thereof as may serve to identify the vehicle with the proceedings enumerated in this section required. 
(Code 1986, § 13-112) 
Secs. 86-148-86-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ROTATIONAL WRECKER SERVICE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-1009-013, adopted September 28, 2010, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as article IV, sections 86-181-86-184 is at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 86-181. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this general order is to establish policy, procedures, and guidelines for providing a rotational wrecker service for towing vehicles under direction of the city police department. 
(Ord. No. O-1009-013, 9-28-2010) 
Sec. 86-182. - Policy. 
    It shall be the policy of the city police department to utilize only those wrecker services whose equipment, procedures, and services to the herein stated rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. O-1009-013, 9-28-2010) 
Sec. 86-183. - Discussion. 
    In the course of providing traffic law enforcement related services to the city, it is frequently necessary to obtain the services of a wrecker due to incidents such as traffic accidents, criminal activity, abandoned vehicles, etc. Occasionally, the owner/operator of a vehicle to be towed is not present to request a particular wrecker service; therefore the bureau rotation wrecker shall be utilized. It shall be the responsibility of officers to adhere to policy set forth in this general order and for participating wrecker services to adhere to the following standards and regulations. It shall be the responsibility of the administrative services division commander for administration and maintenance of this general order. Any modifications, alterations, or changes shall be approved by the chief of police. All members requiring the assistance of a wrecker service shall abide by the procedures and guidelines set forth in this general order. 
(Ord. No. O-1009-013, 9-28-2010) 
Sec. 86-184. - Procedures. 
    Rotation wrecker service policy and standards: 
(1)  Police department call list. 
a.  The police department will maintain a call list of each wrecker service participating in the rotation wrecker service. (All classes-A, B, and C.) 
b.  The bureau will normally follow a set rotation list. 
Exceptions to this rule would include: if a specialized service is needed, or if the owner/operator chooses to request his/her own service. The officer will request the communication office to call the wrecker of the subject's choice. A reasonable length of time will be given to an owner/operator to obtain the wrecker of his/her choice. 
c.  Communications shall keep a record of each time a wrecker is called. The following shall be documented on the record: 
1.  Date of call; 
2.  Time of call; 
3.  Wrecker service called; 
4.  If the call is requested wrecker or a rotation wrecker call; 
5.  The officer making the request for service; 
6.  Location/destination of the wrecker call; 
7.  If wrecker is responding or not; 
8.  If not, why; and 
9.  Operator making the call. 
d.  The wrecker service agrees to pay an administrative fee of $30.00 per month. This fee may be paid yearly at the time of purchase of a business license. 
(2)  Original applications. 
a.  Wrecker service proprietors wishing to have their service included on the police call list shall submit a request to the chief of police. 
b.  Any wrecker service utilized by the department shall be properly licensed and insured. 
c.  All wrecker and storage facilities shall be inspected by the department and proof of insurance filed prior to being placed on the department call list. 
d.  Insurance must be sufficient to compensate for any loss of, or damage to, property entrusted to the wrecker service. 
1.  Vehicle liability-Minimum requirements as set by state law. 
2.  Garage keeper's legal liability-To cover loss by fire, theft, etc. 
e.  Wrecker service operators will cause insurance agents to submit verification of coverage to the chief of police. 
f.  Wrecker service will sign a contract with the Milledgeville Police Department to be placed on the list. 
(3)  Annual inspection and renewal. 
a.  In December, a letter of renewal will be mailed to the wrecker services. The wrecker services will have 30 days to respond to the letter. 
b.  All wreckers and storage facilities shall be inspected annually in January. 
c.  The annual inspection of wrecker services shall include the checking of equipment, insurance, tow and storage rates, etc. 
d.  Certificates of insurance must be submitted at this time. 
e.  Insurance carriers shall notify the chief of police within five days if a policy is cancelled. 
f.  Any changes of insurance coverage, i.e., changing companies, vehicles, etc., will be submitted to the chief of police within ten days. 
g.  The chief of police may have a wrecker service inspected at any time if the circumstances warrant. 
h.  After the completion of each inspection, the chief of police shall inform the administrative services division commander whether the wrecker service will be added to or taken off the call list. 
i.  The public service commission must certify the wrecker service. Proof of certification will be updated at the same time insurance is validated. Any company suspended by the PSC for any reason will notify the city police department immediately. The company will also be suspended from the rotation list until proof of reinstatement by the PSC is provided. 
j.  The wrecker service will provide a copy of current vehicle registration for each truck in operation. This will be updated at the time insurance is validated. 
k.  The wrecker service will provide a truck inspection form filled out by a certified mechanic according to DOT regulations for each truck. 
The wrecker service must have a current occupation tax. 
(4)  Equipment. 
a.  It is essential that the wrecker service have a unit capable of highly efficient performance at the incident scene. 
b.  Emergency equipment. 
1.  At least one amber-colored flashing type light shall be mounted on the top of the wrecker. The department will approve no other color. All emergency flashers and directional lights showing to the front must be amber in color. 
2.  Sirens on wreckers or service trucks are prohibited. 
c.  The following additional equipment is required: 
1.  At least one heavy-duty push broom. 
2.  Flood lights on hoist to illuminate the scene at night. 
3.  One shovel. 
4.  Minimum of one five-pound Class ABC undercover laboratory approved fire extinguisher. 
d.  Appearance of wreckers shall be reasonably good. 
e.  All tow trucks shall display the firm's name, address, and phone number. Such information shall be painted on or permanently affixed to both sides and such lettering shall be at least three inches high. 
Magnetic signs will not be permitted. 
f.  It shall be the responsibility of the wrecker service to have equipment for removing glass and other debris from the highway accident scene. It is the responsibility of the wrecker operator to remove such debris from the highway (T.C.A. 55-8-170). 
(5)  Storage facilities. 
a.  Wrecker services must be equipped to provide a fenced-in lighted lot or building for proper and safe storage. 
1.  It must be located on the property of the wrecker service. 
2.  The wrecker service will be responsible for the storage, safekeeping, and prevention of vandalism of vehicles and contents. 
b.  Records of vehicles towed and charges of calls given from the city police department of police rotation service shall be open to the chief of police. 
(6)  Services and procedures. 
a.  Tow trucks shall be available for immediate response 24 hours a day. 
1.  They must respond in a reasonable length of time or the next scheduled wrecker will be called and the first one will lose their turn. (Reasonable length of time shall be 30 minutes from the time called). If and when the initial wrecker service arrives, the officer will advise the operator that they have lost their turn due to delayed response. 
2.  A responding wrecker(s) must be one displaying the firm's name as called for by the department. Tag, title, and insurance must be in the wrecker service named. 
3.  Wrecker services cannot refer a call to another wrecker company or substitute another company's wrecker service to avoid losing a turn on the call list. 
b.  Wrecker service operators agree not to perform repair work on a "tow-in" without the owner's permission. 
c.  Hold orders placed by the department on vehicles stored for any reason shall be honored by the wrecker establishment. 
d.  The police department shall give a written release when a hold is lifted. 
e.  All other "tow-ins" will be released at the owners request after proof of ownership is established and the necessary financial transactions between vehicle owner and wrecker service are completed. 
f.  No wrecker shall remove a wrecked vehicle without it being investigated by a law enforcement agency. 
g.  Soliciting at the scene is prohibited by the owner, operator, or representative of any wrecker concern. 
h.  All wrecker services shall be prohibited from "chasing" or running wrecks without a bona fide call from the department, dispatcher or request from the owner. Wreckers arriving or stopping at the scene of accidents without being called may assist in clearing the scene, but are prohibited from towing any cars involved in the accident. 
i.  If a wrecker operator desires to be off-duty for any length of time, he/she will not lose his/her place on the call list if they advise the department. When returning, they shall be placed back on the rotation list. 
j.  A wrecker operator who fails to answer his/her call will lost the call. If they miss three consecutive calls in a 30-day period, an investigation shall be made by the department and suspension or removal will be considered. 
k.  An operator who fails to respond promptly to calls may be removed from the call list. 
l.  An operator who refuses a call without just reason shall be removed from the call list. 
m.  A wrecker service shall not be allowed to pull more than one vehicle from an accident scene unless no other wreckers are available. 
n.  When two vehicles are involved and two wreckers are called: 
1.  The first wrecker arriving at the scene will tow the vehicle causing the greatest traffic hazard, which shall be determined by the investigating officer. 
2.  Wrecker drivers are responsible for cleaning all glass and debris from the streets left as a result of the accident. 
Drivers shall check with an officer prior to beginning clean-up activities to ensure evidence is not disturbed. 
o.  When a wrecker service must be called and a specific request is not made by the owner/operator of the vehicle, the wrecker rotational schedule maintained by the communication center shall be utilized. 
p.  The wrecker service on-call at that particular time shall be called to pull in the vehicle in question. 
q.  When a wrecker service is called, that service shall be placed at the bottom of the call list unless the requesting officer advises the communication officer to place that wrecker service back on top of the list. 
r.  The following shall be cause for a wrecker service to be placed back on top of the rotation list: 
1.  The vehicle is released to the owner or for some reason not towed. 
2.  A wrecker company is requested and also the rotation wrecker in the same incident, the service will be used as per request and then placed on top of the rotation list so as not to lose a turn. 
3.  When a vehicle that appears to have been abandoned and an officer requests a rotation wrecker and the owner/operator or wrecker service summoned by the owner/operator arrives prior to the rotation wrecker taking the said vehicle, then the vehicle shall be released to the owner/operator, or request wrecker service. 
s.  Owners shall not be permitted to operate wrecker equipment under more than one company name, out of one location. 
t.  All wrecker service operators are expected to be familiar with and abide by all traffic laws of the state. 
(7)  Complaints and grievance process. 
a.  The department shall investigate all complaints of service and/or charges. 
b.  The administrative division commander shall meet with the parties involved to resolve the complaints. 
c.  If the complaint is not resolved during discussions with the administrative division commander, he shall forward a report to the chief of police. The written report shall contain the following principle elements. 
1.  What the complaint is about and the facts on which it is based. 
2.  The alleged violation of the rule, order, regulation, procedure, right, or harm done. 
3.  The remedy or adjustment sought. 
4.  Date and time submitted to chief of police. 
d.  The chief of police will meet with the parties involved to try to resolve the complaint. If the chief of police cannot resolve the conflict he will forward the report to the public safety committee. 
e.  The mayor and council resolution shall be final and the grievance shall be considered resolved. 
f.  Any valid complaints of over charges by any wrecker service shall result in the following suspension of towing privileges: 
First violation-30 days. 
Second violation-Six months. 
Third violation-Two years. 
Fourth violation-Permanent. 
g.  Failure to comply with any rule and regulation may result in a wrecker service being removed from the rotation list by the mayor and council. 
Owner/operators of wrecker services shall be notified in writing by the chief of police or his/her designated representative of suspension or removal and a copy forwarded to the mayor and council. 
h.  Wrecker rotation grievance procedures. 
1.  Only matters involving interpretation, application, or enforcement of wrecker rotation rules and regulations, as they apply to wrecker service owners and all enforcers of the policy set forth for wrecker rotation, shall constitute a grievance under these provisions. Grievances may be pursued/appealed through this process as high as the mayor and council. 
A.  A grievance may be brought by administrative division commander or wrecker service representative. 
B.  Time limitations are outlined in the grievance process steps. Failure by the aggrieved person to follow time limits will void the grievance. Failure of a superior to follow time limits will be reported in writing, to the chief of police by the aggrieved party. The chief of police shall take steps to ascertain the validity of the time violation and may go ahead and hear the complaint personally. 
C.  Responsibility for coordination of the procedures shall rest with the administrative division commander. Once grievances are completed, they will be placed in the individual's/wrecker service's file. 
2.  Steps: 
A.  Grievances shall be resolved in a timely and orderly manner as outlined in the steps specified by this order. 
B.  Step one (nothing in writing needed at this step). 
i.  The aggrieved party shall meet with the administrative division commander within seven calendar days of the grievance occurrence or within seven calendar days of his/her knowledge of the occurrence and orally discuss the grievance. 
ii.  The commander shall make a decision and orally communicate this decision to the aggrieved party within five calendar days of the presentation of the grievance. Every effort shall be made by the aggrieved and the commander to resolved the grievance at this level. 
C.  Step two. 
i.  If the grievance is not resolved during discussion with the commander, the aggrieved shall submit a written grievance form within five calendar days following the commanders oral response. The written grievance at this and all subsequent steps shall contain the following principle elements: 
(A)  What the grievance is about and the facts on which it is based; 
(B)  The alleged violation of the rule, order, regulation, procedure or right and the harm done: 
(C)  The remedy or adjustment sought; and 
(D)  The signature of the aggrieved and the date of submission. 
ii.  The chief of police shall respond in writing to this grievance within five calendar days. Receipts of the grievance shall be acknowledged by the date, time, and signature of the person receiving the grievance. The written response at this and subsequent steps shall contain the following information: 
(A)  An analysis of the alleged violation: 
(B)  A statement of affirming or denying the allegations in the grievance; 
(C)  The remedy or adjustment to be made, if any; and 
(D)  Signature of the chief of police and date completed. 
iii.  At this and subsequent steps the chief of police may meet with the aggrieved and others to resolve the grievance. The aggrieved will have a second interview with the chief of police upon his/her completion of the grievance. 
D.  Step three. The mayor and council shall review the grievance and agree or disagree with the chief of police findings. The mayor and councils resolution shall be final and the grievance shall be considered resolved. 
E.  Analysis. An annual review of grievances will be done to determine if a trend exist in filed grievances. The review will be used determine if any changes are needed in this policy. 
(8)  Towing charges. 
a.  Towing and storage rates shall be determined and established on an annual basis by mayor and council. 
b.  The towing rate shall be set per rate schedule. 
c.  The storage rate shall be set per rate schedule. 
d.  Wrecker services agree to tow city owned vehicles for $35.00. 
(9)  [Conflict.] This policy shall not be construed in any way to conflict with General Order 10-2, revised impound/tow policy. 
(Ord. No. O-1009-013, 9-28-2010)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 90-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act or the Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, Public Law 92-500 as amended by PL 95-217, PL 97-117 and PL 100-4 and as now or hereafter amended, also known as the Clean Water Act, 33 USC 1251 et seq. 
    Approval authority means the State of Georgia, department of natural resources, environmental protection division (EPD). 
    Approved POTW treatment program shall mean a program administered by a POTW that meets the criteria established in 40 CFR 403.8 and 40 CFR 403.9 and which has been approved by the approval authority in accordance with 40 CFR 403.11. 
    Authorized representative of the user. 
(a)  If the user is a corporation: 
(1)  The president, secretary, treasurer, or a vice-president of the corporation in charge of a principal business function, or any other person who performs similar policy or decision-making functions for the corporation; or 
(2)  The manager of one or more manufacturing, production, or operation facilities employing more than 250 persons or having gross annual sales or expenditures exceeding $25,000,000.00 (in second-quarter 1980 dollars), if authority to sign documents has been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordance with corporate procedures. 
(b)  If the user is a partnership or sole proprietorship: a general partner or proprietor, respectively. 
(c)  If the user is a federal, state, or local governmental facility: a director or highest official appointed or designated to oversee the operation and performance of the activities of the government facility, or their designee. 
(d)  The individuals described in subsections (a) through (c), above, may designate another authorized representative if the authorization is in writing, the authorization specifies the individual or position responsible for the overall operation of the facility from which the discharge originates or having overall responsibility for environmental matters for the company and the written authorization is submitted to the director. 
    Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) shall mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in terms of milligrams per liter. 
    Building sewer shall mean the extension from a building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal.
